column3: question
column4: a
column5: b
column6: c
column7: d

column3: A homeowner was injured when an automatic cutoff switch failed to function on a snowblower he was using. The cutoff switch had functioned well for a year after he purchased the snowblower but failed after the machine had been improperly repaired by a mechanic. The snowblower's operating manual contained a clear and prominent warning against making the very alteration to the switch mechanism that was made by the mechanic. The mechanic, however, did not have a manual available when he repaired the snowblower. Does the homeowner have a viable claim against the manufacturer of the snowblower for damages?
column4: No, because the homeowner was contributorily negligent in failing to furnish the snowblower's manual to the mechanic.
column5: No, because the injury resulted from a substantial alteration of the snowblower by a third party.
column6: Yes, because a defect in the snowblower caused the homeowner's injury.
column7: Yes, because the manufacturer should have made the manual available to repair personnel.

column3: On August 1, a company operating a “lifetime care” home for the elderly admitted an 84 year old man for a trial period of two months. On September 25, the man and the Company entered into a written lifetime care contract with an effective commencement date of October 1. The full contract price was $20,000, which, as required by the terms of the contract, the man prepaid to the Company on September 25. The man died of a heart attack on October 2. In a restitutionary action, can the administratrix of the man’s estate, a surviving sister, recover on behalf of the estate either all or part of the $20,000 paid to the Company on September 25?
column4: Yes, because the Company would otherwise be unjustly enriched at the man’s expense.
column5: Yes, under the doctrine of frustration of purpose.
column6: No, because the man’s life span and the duration of the Company’s commitment to him was a risk assumed by both parties.
column7: No, but only if the Company can show that between September 25 and the man’s death it rejected, because of its commitment to the man, an application for lifetime care from another elderly person.

column3: While walking home one evening, an off-duty police officer was accosted by a stranger. The stranger had been drinking and mistakenly thought the officer was a man who was having an affair with his wife. Intending to frighten the officer but not to harm him, the stranger pulled out a knife, screamed obscenities, and told the officer he was going to kill him. Frightened and reasonably believing the stranger was going to kill him and that using deadly force was his only salvation, the officer took out his service revolver and shot and killed the stranger. The officer is charged with murder.The officer’s claim of self-defense should be
column4: sustained, because the officer reasonably believed the stranger was planning to kill him and that deadly force was required.
column5: sustained, because the killing was in hot blood upon sufficient provocation.
column6: denied, because the stranger did not in fact intend to harm the officer and the officer was incorrect in believing that he did.
column7: denied, because the officer was not defending his home and had an obligation to retreat or to repel with less than deadly force.

column3: A woman entered a hospital to undergo surgery and feared that she might not survive. She instructed her lawyer by telephone to prepare a deed conveying a large tract of undeveloped land, as a gift to her nephew, who lived in a distant state. Her instructions were followed, and, prior to her surgery, she executed a document in a form sufficient to constitute a deed of conveyance. The deed was recorded by the lawyer promptly as she instructed him to do. The recorded deed was returned to the lawyer by the land record office. The woman, in fact, recovered from her surgery and the lawyer returned the recorded deed to her. Before the woman or the lawyer thought to inform the nephew of the conveyance, the nephew was killed in an auto accident. The nephew’s will left all of his estate to a satanic religious cult. The woman was very upset at the prospect of the cult’s acquiring the tract. The local taxing authority assessed the next real property tax bill on the tract to the nephew’s estate. The woman brought the appropriate action against the nephew’s estate and the cult to set aside the conveyance to the nephew. If the woman loses, it will be because
column4: the gift of the tract was inter vivos rather than causa mortis.
column5: the showing of the nephew’s estate as the owner of the tract on the tax rolls supplied what otherwise would be a missing essential element for a valid conveyance.
column6: disappointing the nephew’s devisee would violate the religious freedom provisions of the First Amendment to the Constitution.
column7: delivery of the deed is presumed from the recording of the deed.

column3: In a prosecution of a woman for murder, the government seeks to introduce a properly authenticated note written by the victim that reads: "Woman did it." In laying the foundation for admitting the note as a dying declaration, the prosecution offered an affidavit from the attending physician that the victim knew she was about to die when she wrote the note. The admissibility of the note as a dying declaration is:
column4: a preliminary fact question for the judge, and the judge must not consider the affidavit;
column5: a preliminary fact question for the judge, and the judge may properly consider the affidavit;
column6: a question of weight and credibility for the jury, and the jury must not consider the affidavit;
column7: a question of weight and credibility for the jury, and the jury may properly consider the affidavit.

column3: A bartender was removing the restraining wire from a bottle of champagne produced and bottled by a winery. The plastic stopper suddenly shot out of the bottle. The stopper struck and injured the bartender's eye. The bartender had opened other bottles of champagne, and occasionally the stoppers had shot out with great force, but the bartender had not been injured. The bartender has brought an action against the winery, alleging that the bottle that caused his injury was defective and unreasonably dangerous because its label did not warn that the stopper might suddenly shoot out during opening. The state has merged contributory negligence and unreasonable assumption of risk into a pure comparative fault system that is applied in strict products liability actions. If the jury finds that the bottle was defective and unreasonably dangerous because it lacked a warning, will the bartender recover a judgment in his favor?
column4: No, if the jury finds that a legally sufficient warning would not have prevented the bartender's injury;
column5: No, if a reasonable bartender would have realized that a stopper could eject from the bottle and hit his eye;
column6: Yes, with damages reduced by the percentage of any contributory fault on the bartender's part;
column7: Yes, with no reduction in damages, because foreseeable lack of caution is the reason for requiring a warning.

column3: A man, a resident of California, is injured when the automobile he is driving is struck by a vehicle negligently driven by a second man, a resident of New Mexico. The second man claims he was forced to collide with the man by the negligent driving of a woman, a resident of California. The man sues the second man in Federal Court in California, claiming diversity jurisdiction and damages of $100,000. The second man impleads the woman on a third-party claim for contribution. The woman moves to dismiss on the grounds of lack of diversity. The woman’s motion should be:
column4: Granted, because the woman and the man are not diverse of citizenship.
column5: Granted, because the California Federal Court lacks proper venue.
column6: Denied, because the claim between the woman and the second man arises from the same common nucleus of facts as the original claim.
column7: Denied, because diversity rules do not apply to FRCP 14 impleaders.

column3: An interstate bus company operates in a five-state area. A federal statute authorizes the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) to permit interstate carriers to discontinue entirely any unprofitable route. The bus company applied to the ICC for permission to drop a very unprofitable route through a sparsely populated mountain range. The ICC granted that permission even though the bus company provided the only public transportation into the region. A man is the owner of a mountain resort in the mountain range, whose customers usually arrived on vehicles operated by the bus company. After exhausting all available federal administrative remedies, the man filed suit against the bus company in the trial court of the state in which the mountain range is located to enjoin the discontinuance by the bus company of its service to that area. The man alleged that the discontinuance of service by the bus company would violate a statute of that state prohibiting common carriers of persons from abandoning service to communities having no alternate form of public transportation. The state court should:
column4: dismiss the action, because the man lacks standing to sue.
column5: direct the removal of the case to federal court, because this suit involves a substantial federal question.
column6: hear the case on its merits and decide for the man because, on these facts, a federal agency is interfering with essential state functions.
column7: hear the case on its merits and decide for the bus company, because a valid federal law preempts the state statute on which the man relies.

column3: A man decided to destroy his dilapidated building in order to collect the insurance money. He hired an arsonist to burn down the building. The arsonist broke into the building and carefully searched it to make sure no one was inside. He failed, however, to see a vagrant asleep in an office closet. He started a fire. The building was destroyed, and the vagrant died from burns a week later. Two days after the fire, the man filed an insurance claim in which he stated that he had no information about the cause of the fire. If the man is guilty of felony-murder, it is because the vagrant’s death occurred in connection with the felony of
column4: arson.
column5: fraud.
column6: conspiracy.
column7: burglary.

column3: Plaintiff challenged the constitutionality of a state tax law, alleging that it violated the equal protection clauses of both the United States Constitution and the state constitution. The state supreme court agreed and held the tax law to be invalid. It said: "We hold that this state tax law violates the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution and also the equal protection clause of the state constitution because we interpret that provision of the state constitution to contain exactly the same prohibition against discriminatory legislation as is contained in the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution." The state sought review of this decision in the United States Supreme Court, alleging that the state supreme court's determination of the federal constitutional issue was incorrect. How should the United States Supreme Court dispose of the case if it believes that this interpretation of the federal Constitution by the state supreme court raises an important federal question and is incorrect on the merits?
column4: Reverse the state supreme court decision, because the equal protection clause of a state constitution must be construed by the state supreme court in a manner that is congruent with the meaning of the equal protection clause of the federal Constitution.
column5: Reverse the state supreme court decision with respect to the equal protection clause of the federal Constitution and remand the case to the state supreme court for further proceedings, because the state and federal constitutional issues are so intertwined that the federal issue must be decided so that this case may be disposed of properly.
column6: Refuse to review the decision of the state supreme court, because it is based on an adequate and independent ground of state law.
column7: Refuse to review the decision of the state supreme court, because a state government may not seek review of decisions of its own courts in the United States Supreme Court.

column3: A federal statute prohibits the construction of nuclear energy plants in this country without a license from the Federal Nuclear Plant Siting Commission. The statute provides that the Commission may issue a license authorizing the construction of a proposed nuclear energy plant 30 days after the Commission makes a finding that the plant will comply with specified standards of safety, technological and commercial feasibility, and public convenience. In a severable provision, the Commission's enabling statute also provides that the Congress, by simple majorities in each house, may veto the issuance of a particular license by the Commission if such a veto occurs within 30 days following the required Commission finding. Early last year, the Commission found that a company met all statutory requirements and, therefore, voted to issue the company a license authorizing it to construct a nuclear energy plant. Because they believed that the issuance of a license the company was not in accord with the applicable statutory criteria, a majority of each of the two houses of Congress voted, within the specified 30-day period, to veto the license. On the basis of that veto, the Commission refused to issue the license. Subsequently, the company sued the Commission in an appropriate federal district court, challenging the constitutionality of the Commission's refusal to issue the license. In this suit, the court should hold the congressional veto of the license of the company to be:
column4: invalid, because any determination by Congress that particular agency action does not satisfy statutory criteria violates Article III, Section 1 of the Constitution because it constitutes the performance of a judicial function by the legislative branch.
column5: invalid, because Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution has been interpreted to mean that any action of Congress purporting to alter the legal rights of persons outside of the legislative branch must be presented to the President for his signature or veto.
column6: valid, because Congress has authority under the commerce clause to regulate the construction of nuclear energy plants.
column7: valid, because there is a compelling national interest in the close congressional supervision of nuclear plant siting in light of the grave dangers to the public health and safety that are associated with the operation of such plants.

column3: A man became ill while at work and decided to go home early. When he entered his bedroom, the man saw his wife engaged in sexual intercourse with a neighbor. The man grabbed a gun from a dresser drawer and shot and killed the neighbor. He was later charged and prosecuted. In a jurisdiction that follows the common law for homicide offenses, which crimes should the court instruct the jury on?
column4: Murder and involuntary manslaughter.
column5: Murder and voluntary manslaughter.
column6: Murder, voluntary manslaughter, and involuntary manslaughter.
column7: Voluntary manslaughter and involuntary manslaughter.

column3: A railroad worker's widow brought a wrongful death action in federal court against the railroad, claiming that its negligence had caused her husband's death. At trial, the widow offered the testimony of a coworker of the husband. The coworker testified that he had seen the rail car on which the husband was riding slow down and the cars behind it gain speed. The coworker also stated that he later heard a loud crash, but did not turn around to look because loud noises were common in the yard. Three other railroad employees testified that no collision had occurred. At the close of the evidence, the railroad moved for judgment as a matter of law, which was denied, and the case was submitted to the jury. The jury returned a verdict for the widow. The railroad has made a renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law. What standard should the court apply to determine how to rule on the motion?
column4: Whether the evidence revealed a genuine dispute of material fact supporting the widow's claim.
column5: Whether the verdict is against the weight of the evidence.
column6: Whether the widow presented a scintilla of evidence to support the verdict.
column7: Whether there is substantial evidence in the record to support the verdict, resolving all disputed issues in the widow's favor.

column3: A man, a resident of California, is injured when the automobile he is driving is struck by a vehicle negligently driven by a second man, a resident of New Mexico. The man sues the second man in Federal Court in California for negligence, alleging that the second man ran a red light. The second man denies the allegation and tells his attorney that the man ran a red light. The second man’s attorney visits the scene of the accident and determines that a woman, an employee at the coffee shop located at the intersection where the accident occurred, witnessed the accident. The woman tells the second man’s attorney that the second man ran a red light. Which of the following statements is correct?
column4: The second man’s attorney must disclose to the man’s attorney the woman’s name, address and telephone number as part of the initial disclosures.
column5: The second man’s attorney’s notes of his interview with the woman are protected work product.
column6: If the man propounds an interrogatory on the second man asking for the names and addresses of all witnesses to the accident, the second man’s attorney may refuse to disclose the woman’s name and address as privileged information.
column7: The second man’s attorney will violate Rule 11 if he signs and files an answer denying that the second man ran a red light.

column3: Two students are in an advanced high school Russian class. During an argument one day in the high school cafeteria, in the presence of other students, first student, in Russian, accused second student of taking money from first student's locker. In a suit by second student against first student based on defamation, second student will:
column4: prevail, because first student's accusation constituted slander per se;
column5: prevail, because the defamatory statement was made in the presence of third persons;
column6: not prevail, unless first student made the accusation with knowledge of falsity or reckless disregard of the truth;
column7: not prevail, unless one or more of the other students understood Russian.

column3: Congressional hearings determined that the use of mechanical power hammers is very dangerous to the persons using them and to persons in the vicinity of the persons using them. As a result, Congress enacted a statute prohibiting the use of mechanical power hammers on all construction projects in the United States. Subsequently, a study conducted by a private research firm concluded that nails driven by mechanical power hammers have longer-lasting joining power than hand-driven nails. After learning about this study, the city council of a City enacted an amendment to its building safety code requiring the use of mechanical power hammers in the construction of all buildings intended for human habitation. This amendment to the City’s building safety code is:
column4: unconstitutional, because it was enacted subsequent to the federal statute.
column5: unconstitutional, because it conflicts with the provisions of the federal statute.
column6: constitutional, because the federal statute does not expressly indicate that it supersedes inconsistent state or local laws.
column7: constitutional, because the long-term safety of human habitations justifies some additional risk to the people engaged in their construction.

column3: The attorney for a plaintiff in an action filed in federal district court served the defendant with the summons, the complaint, and 25 interrogatories asking questions about the defendant's contentions in the case. The interrogatories stated that they were to be answered within 30 days after service.The defendant is likely to succeed in obtaining a protective order on which of the following grounds?
column4: Interrogatories are only proper to discover facts, not contentions.
column5: Interrogatories may not be served until an answer to the complaint is filed.
column6: Interrogatories may not be served until the parties have conferred to arrange for initial disclosures and prepare a discovery plan.
column7: The interrogatories exceed the number permitted without permission from the court or an agreement between the parties.

column3: A plaintiff brought a negligence action against a defendant. The plaintiff presented one witness, a long-time criminal who was intoxicated when he observed the alleged negligent acts. During trial, the defendant’s cross-examination of the witness revealed that he had provided false or incorrect testimony on several key facts. The defendant then presented the testimony of her own witnesses, consisting of the chair of the ethics committee of the state bar, two nuns, and the plaintiff’s parents, all of whom were eye-witnesses to the alleged negligent acts with perfect vision. Defendant made no motions during trial. The jury found in favor of plaintiff. What motion should the defendant make?
column4: Motion for summary judgment.
column5: Motion for a directed verdict.
column6: Motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.
column7: Motion for a new trial.

column3: A defendant is on trial for the brutal murder of the victim. The defendant's first witness testified that in her opinion the defendant is a peaceful and nonviolent person. The prosecution does not cross-examine the witness, who is then excused from further attendance. Which one of the following is INADMISSIBLE during the prosecution's rebuttal?
column4: Testimony by the witness' former employer that the witness submitted a series of false expense vouchers two years ago.
column5: Testimony by a police officer that the defendant has a long-standing reputation in the community as having a violent temper.
column6: Testimony by a neighbor that the witness has a long-standing reputation in the community as an untruthful person.
column7: Testimony by the defendant's former cell mate that he overheard the witness offer to provide favorable testimony if the defendant would pay her $5,000.

column3: A seller contracted to sell land to a buyer for $300,000. The contract provided that the closing would be 60 days after the contract was signed and that the seller would convey to the buyer a "marketable title" by a quitclaim deed at closing. The contract contained no other provisions regarding the title to be delivered to the buyer. A title search revealed that the land was subject to an unsatisfied $50,000 mortgage and a right-of-way easement over a portion of the land. The buyer now claims that the title is unmarketable and has refused to close. Is the buyer correct?
column4: No, because nothing under these facts renders title unmarketable.
column5: No, because the buyer agreed to accept a quitclaim deed.
column6: Yes, because the right-of-way easement makes the title unmarketable.
column7: Yes, because the unsatisfied mortgage makes the title unmarketable.

column3: City has had a severe traffic problem on its streets. As a result, it enacted an ordinance prohibiting all sales to the public of food or other items by persons selling directly from trucks, cars, or other vehicles located on city streets. The ordinance included an inseverable grandfather provision exempting from its prohibition vendors who, for 20 years or more, have continuously sold food or other items from such vehicles located on the streets of City. A retail vendor of ice cream products, qualifies for this exemption and is the only food vendor that does. A yogurt company is a business similar to the retail vendor, but the yogurt company has been selling to the public directly from trucks located on the streets of City only for the past ten years. The yogurt company filed suit in an appropriate federal, district court to enjoin enforcement of this ordinance on the ground that it denies the yogurt company the equal protection of the laws. In this case, the court will probably rule that the ordinance is:
column4: constitutional, because it is narrowly tailored to implement City's compelling interest in reducing traffic congestion and, therefore, satisfies the strict scrutiny test applicable to such cases.
column5: constitutional, because its validity is governed by the rational basis test, and the courts consistently defer to economic choices embodied in such legislation if they are even plausibly justifiable.
column6: unconstitutional, because the nexus between the legitimate purpose of the ordinance and the conduct it prohibits is so tenuous and its provisions are so underinclusive that the ordinance fails to satisfy the substantial relationship test applicable to such cases.
column7: unconstitutional, because economic benefits or burdens imposed by legislatures on the basis of grandfather provisions have consistently been declared invalid by courts as per se violations of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

column3: The Governor of State signed a death warrant for a convicted murderer. At a demonstration protesting the execution of murderer, demonstrators carried large signs that stated, "Governor Is A Murderer." A television station broadcast news coverage of the demonstration, including pictures of the signs carried by demonstrators. If the Governor asserts a defamation claim against the television station, will the Governor prevail?
column4: Yes, because the signs would cause persons to hold the Governor in lower esteem.
column5: Yes, if the Governor proves that television station showed the signs with knowledge of falsity or reckless disregard of the truth that the Governor had not committed homicide.
column6: No, unless the Governor proves he suffered pecuniary loss resulting from harm to his reputation proximately caused by the defendants' signs.
column7: No, if the only reasonable interpretation of the signs was that the term "murderer" was intended as a characterization of one who would sign a death warrant.

column3: A plaintiff seeks to obtain a default judgment against the defendant in Federal Court, after defendant fails to timely file an Answer to Plaintiff’s Complaint. Which of the following facts, if true, will block Plaintiff from obtaining her default judgment, even if all other procedural and substantive requirements are met?
column4: Defendant is 17 years old and unrepresented by a guardian, conservator, or similar fiduciary.
column5: Defendant files his answer one day late.
column6: Plaintiff’s complaint seeks damages “in the amount of $300,000 plus interest at the legal rate.”
column7: Defendant was served while in the state, but is currently on a vacation in Europe.

column3: On July 18, a shovel manufacturer received an order for the purchase of 500 snow shovels from a wholesaler. The wholesaler had mailed the purchase order on July 15. The order required shipment of the shovels no earlier than September 15 and no later than October 15. Typed conspicuously across the front of the order form was the following: “Wholesaler reserves the right to cancel this order at any time before September 1.” The manufacturer’s mailed response, saying, “We accept your order,” was received by the wholesaler on July 21. As of July 22, which of the following is an accurate statement as to whether a contract was formed?
column4: No contract was formed, because of the wholesaler’s reservation of the right to cancel.
column5: No contract was formed, because the wholesaler’s order was only a revocable offer.
column6: A contract was formed, but prior to September 1 it was terminable at the will of either party.
column7: A contract was formed, but prior to September 1 it was an option contract terminable only at the will of wholesaler.

column3: During an ice storm, a man's car slipped down an embankment and became lodged against a large tree. The man called a towing company and told the company's manager that the car was 100 feet down the embankment. "That's lucky," said the manager, "because our winch only goes 100 feet." After the manager and the man agreed on a price, an employee of the company attempted to reach the car but could not because the car turned out to be 120 feet down the embankment. Is the towing company's performance excused on the grounds of mistake?
column4: No, because both parties were uncertain about the distance.
column5: No, because the towing company assumed the risk by the manager's failure to examine the distance himself.
column6: Yes, because at the time of contracting, both parties were mistaken about a basic assumption on which the contract was based.
column7: Yes, because the agreement did not allocate the risk of mistake to either party.

column3: In the case of Plaintiff v. Defendant Automotive, a products liability case involving a claim that the engine of the “Defendant Dynamo,” an automobile manufactured by Defendant was defectively designed, the following actions occurred inside the jury room during deliberations. Deliberations resulted in a defense verdict. Which of the actions is the best grounds for Plaintiff to seek a new trial based on jury misconduct?
column4: Juror No. 5, an engineer by education and training, tells the other jurors that Plaintiff’s expert’s testimony concerning a feasible alternative design is inconsistent with his understanding of the engineering principles involved.
column5: Juror Nos. 7 and 11 engage in a three-minute shouting match, followed by a very brief shove of the other by each of them, after which everyone calmed down.
column6: Juror No. 2 fails to say anything or give any opinion whatsoever in the deliberations, but does vote in favor of defendant.
column7: Juror No. 1, over the weekend, takes a “Defendant Dynamo” for a test drive, and then tells the jurors on the following Monday during deliberations that he tried to duplicate what Plaintiff said happened when he was injured, but the engine worked well.

column3: A police officer was employed on a city's police force for 10 years. When the officer accepted the job, the city's employee benefit plan provided a death benefit to the spouse of any employee who died as a result of any job-related injury. Last year, the city amended its employee benefit plan to deny its death benefit in cases where the death "was caused by the employee's refusal to accept, for any reason other than its excessive risk to life or health, reasonably available medical care prescribed by a physician." After this amendment took effect, the officer was shot while on duty. Because of a sincerely held religious belief, the officer refused to allow a prescribed blood transfusion and, as a result, died from loss of blood. When the officer's spouse applied for the death benefit, the city denied the application on the basis of the amendment to the employee benefit plan. The officer's spouse has challenged the amendment, claiming that, as applied to the officer, it violated the officer's constitutional right to the free exercise of religion. Is the court likely to find the amendment to the employee benefit plan constitutional as applied to the officer?
column4: No, because it effectively discriminates against a religious practice.
column5: No, because it violates the vested contractual rights of city employees who were hired before the amendment took effect.
column6: Yes, because it does not single out religious reasons for the denial of benefits and is a reasonable limitation on the award of such benefits.
column7: Yes, because it imposes a condition only on the award of a government benefit and does not impose a penalty on an individual's conduct.

column3: A 15-year-old boy was killed during a gang fight. Two days after his funeral, the boy's mother saw a television program about gang violence and was shocked to see video of herself weeping over the boy's body. The video had been shot by the television reporting team while the boy's body was still lying on a public street. The mother suffered severe emotional distress as a result of seeing the video. If the mother sues the television station for invasion of her privacy and that of her son, will the mother be likely to prevail?
column4: No, because a person has no right to privacy after his or her death.
column5: No, because the street was open to the public and the subject was newsworthy.
column6: Yes, because the mother did not give permission to have the video used in the program.
column7: Yes, because the mother suffered severe emotional distress as a result of viewing the video.

column3: Fifteen years ago, two men who were fishing buddies moved onto vacant rural land owned by a woman they didn't know and built a small fishing shack on it. Twelve years ago, the men replaced the shack with a fish processing plant and a commercial fishing boat dock. The men maintained their commercial fishery operation on the land until one of them died intestate last year, leaving a sole heir. The period of time to acquire title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is 10 years. The woman has now become aware of the changes that have occurred on the land. In an action to determine title, for whom should the court decide?
column4: For the man who is still alive and the deceased man's heir, because the men acquired title as tenants in common.
column5: For the man who is still alive, because he is the surviving adverse possessor.
column6: For the woman, because the use was changed by the men while they were in possession.
column7: For the woman, because title cannot be claimed by two adverse possessors simultaneously.

column3: A high-volume, pleasure-boat retailer entered into a written contract with a man, signed by both parties, to sell the man a power boat for $12,000. The manufacturer’s price of the boat delivered to the retailer was $9,500. As the contract provided, the man paid the retailer $4,000 in advance and promised to pay the full balance upon delivery of the boat. The contract contained no provision for liquidated damages. Prior to the agreed delivery date, the man notified the retailer that he would be financially unable to conclude the purchase; and the retailer thereupon resold the same boat that the man had ordered to a third person for $12,000 cash. If the man sues the retailer for restitution of the $4,000 advance payment, which of the following should the court decide?
column4: The man’s claim should be denied, because, as the party in default, he is deemed to have lost any right to restitution of a benefit conferred on the retailer.
column5: The man’s claim should be denied, because, but for his repudiation, the retailer would have made a profit on two boat-sales instead of one.
column6: The man’s claim should be upheld in the amount of $4,000 minus the amount of the retailer’s lost profit under its contract with the man.
column7: The man’s claims should be upheld in the amount of $3,500 ($4,000 minus $500 as statutory damages under the UCC).

column3: A Plaintiff, a management trainee, brought a sex discrimination lawsuit against her employer for wrongful termination of her employment. At trial, the plaintiff is prepared to testify that a janitor at the company told her that he had heard her supervisor say to other male coworkers about her, "Make it hard for her. Maybe she'll go home where she belongs."Is the plaintiff's proposed testimony admissible?
column4: No, because the janitor's statement is hearsay not within any exception.
column5: No, because the statements of both the janitor and the supervisor are hearsay not within any exception.
column6: Yes, because the janitor's statement is a present sense impression, and the supervisor's statement is a statement of his then-existing state of mind.
column7: Yes, because the statements of both the janitor and the supervisor are statements concerning a matter within the scope of their employment.

column3: A plaintiff sued an industrial facility in her neighborhood for injuries to her health caused by air pollution. At trial, the plaintiff was asked questions on direct examination about the days on which she had observed large amounts of dust in the air and how long the condition had lasted. She testified that she could not remember the specific times, but that she maintained a diary in which she had accurately recorded this information on a daily basis. When her attorney sought to refresh her recollection with her diary, she still could not remember. The plaintiff's attorney seeks to have the information in the diary admitted at trial. Is the information admissible?
column4: No, because reviewing it did not refresh the plaintiff's recollection.
column5: No, unless it is offered by the defendant.
column6: Yes, and the plaintiff should be allowed the option of reading it into evidence or having the diary received as an exhibit.
column7: Yes, and the plaintiff should be allowed to read the diary into evidence.

column3: A buyer and a seller entered into a written contract for the sale of land. The contract satisfied the requirements of the statute of frauds. Because the buyer needed time to obtain financing, the buyer and the seller did not agree upon a closing date, and the written contract did not contain a stated closing date. Ten days after signing the contract, the buyer and the seller orally agreed to rescind the contract. The next day, the seller sold the land to a third party. Two days after that sale, the original buyer told the seller that she had changed her mind and wanted to complete their contract. When the seller told her that he had sold the land to a third party, she sued him for breach of the written contract. For whom will the court find?
column4: For the buyer, because she informed the seller within a reasonable time that she desired to close the transaction.
column5: For the buyer, because the agreement to rescind the contract was not in a writing signed by the buyer and the seller.
column6: For the seller, because the contract failed to contain a stated closing date.
column7: For the seller, because the oral rescission was valid.

column3: Plaintiff sued Defendant for damages arising out of an automobile collision. At trial, Plaintiff called an eyewitness to the collision. Plaintiff expected eyewitness to testify that she had observed Defendant 's automobile for five seconds prior to the collision and estimated Defendant 's speed at the time of the collision to have been 50 miles per hour. Instead, eyewitness testified that she estimated Defendant 's speed to have been 25 miles per hour. Without finally excusing eyewitness as a witness, Plaintiff then called a police officer, to testify that eyewitness had told him during his investigation at the accident scene that Defendant "was doing at least 50." The police officer's testimony is:
column4: admissible as a present sense impression
column5: admissible to impeach eyewitness.
column6: inadmissible, because Plaintiff may not impeach his own witness.
column7: inadmissible, because it is hearsay not within any exception.

column3: After waiting until all the customers had left, a man entered a small grocery store just before closing time. He went up to the lone clerk in the store and said, “Hand over all the money in the cash register or you will get hurt.” The clerk fainted and struck his head on the edge of the counter. As the man went behind the counter to open the cash register, two customers entered the store. The man ran out before he was able to open the register drawer. On this evidence the man could be convicted of
column4: robbery.
column5: assault and robbery.
column6: attempted robbery.
column7: assault and attempted robbery.

column3: A chemical company's plant was located in a residential community. The manufacturing process used at the plant generated a toxic chemical as a byproduct. The chemical was stored in a state-of-the-art tank on the site before being moved to an off-site disposal facility. The on-site storage arrangement conformed to the requirements of reasonable care and to the applicable government regulations. However, the storage of the toxic chemical created a foreseeable and highly significant risk of physical harm even when reasonable care was exercised. Despite the chemical company's proper use and care of the storage tank, toxic fumes escaped from the tank and made residents of the area seriously ill. No state or federal statutes address the issue of the company's liability. In an action by one of the affected residents against the chemical company, will the resident be likely to prevail?
column4: No, because the chemical company conformed to the requirements of reasonable care and to the applicable government regulations.
column5: No, because the chemical company used a state-of-the-art storage tank.
column6: Yes, because the chemical company is strictly liable in tort for any harm caused by the toxic chemicals it produced.
column7: Yes, because the storage of toxic chemicals in a residential community created a highly significant risk of physical harm even when reasonable care was exercised.

column3: Defendant is on trial for burglary. During cross- examination of Defendant, the prosecutor wants to inquire about Defendant's earlier conviction for falsifying a credit application. Which of the following facts concerning the conviction would be the best reason for the trial court's refusing to allow such examination?
column4: Defendant was released from prison 12 years ago.
column5: Defendant was put on probation rather than imprisoned.
column6: It was for a misdemeanor rather than a felony.
column7: It is on appeal.

column3: Police received information from an undercover police officer that she had just seen two men (whom she described) in a red pickup truck selling marijuana to schoolchildren near the city’s largest high school. A few minutes later, two police officers saw a pickup truck fitting the description of one of the men described by the undercover officer. The only passenger was a young woman who was in the back of the truck. The police saw her get out and stand at a nearby bus stop. They stopped the truck and searched the driver. In the pocket of the driver’s jacket, the police found a small bottle of pills that they recognized as narcotics. They then broke open a locked toolbox attached to the flatbed of the truck and found a small sealed envelope inside. They opened it and found marijuana. They also found a quantity of cocaine in the glove compartment. After completing their search of the driver and the truck, the police went over to the young woman and searched her purse. In her purse, they found a small quantity of heroin. Both the driver and the young woman were arrested and charged with unlawful possession of narcotics. If the driver moves to suppress the use as evidence of the marijuana and cocaine found in the search of the truck, the court should
column4: grant the motion as to both the marijuana and the cocaine.
column5: grant the motion as to the marijuana but deny it as to the cocaine.
column6: deny the motion as to the marijuana but grant it as to the cocaine.
column7: deny the motion as to both the marijuana and the cocaine.

column3: A man who believed that his wife was cheating on him with her gym trainer decided to kill the trainer. He loaded his handgun and set off for the trainer's house. Because he was anxious about committing the crime, the man first stopped at a bar, drank eight shots of hard liquor, and became intoxicated. He then left the bar and went to the trainer's house. When the trainer answered the door, the man shot and killed him. The man then passed out on the trainer's porch. The man has been charged with murder in a jurisdiction that follows the common law. Can the man raise an intoxication defense?
column4: No, because drinking at the bar was the proximate cause of the killing.
column5: No, because the man intended to commit the murder and drank to strengthen his nerve.
column6: Yes, because drinking at the bar was a foreseeable intervening cause of the killing.
column7: Yes, because the man's intoxication negated the specific intent required for murder.

column3: A man owned two adjoining parcels known as Lot 1 and Lot 2. Both parcels fronted on Main Street and abutted a public alley in the rear. Lot 1 was improved with a commercial building that covered all of the Main Street frontage of Lot 1; there was a large parking lot on the rear of Lot 1 with access from the alley only. Fifteen years ago, the man leased Lot 1 to a tenant for 15 years. The tenant has continuously occupied Lot 1 since that time. Thirteen years ago, the tenant began to use a driveway on Lot 2 as a better access between Main Street and the parking lot than the alley. Eight years ago, the man conveyed Lot 2 to a woman and, five years ago, the man conveyed Lot 1 to the tenant by a deed that recited “together with all the appurtenances.” Until last week, the tenant continuously used the driveway over Lot 2 to the tenant’s parking lot in the rear of Lot 1. Last week the woman commenced construction of a building on Lot 2 and blocked the driveway used by the tenant. The tenant has commenced an action against the woman to restrain her from blocking the driveway from Main Street to the parking lot at the rear of Lot 1. The period of time to acquire rights by prescription in the jurisdiction is ten years. If the tenant loses, it will be because
column4: The man owned both Lot 1 and Lot 2 until eight years ago.
column5: The tenant has access to the parking lot from the alley.
column6: mere use of an easement is not adverse possession.
column7: no easement was mentioned in the deed from the man to the woman.

column3: A developer, needing a water well on one of his projects, met several times about the matter with a well driller. Subsequently, the driller sent developer an unsigned typewritten form captioned “WELL DRILLING PROPOSAL” and stating various terms the two had discussed but not agreed upon, including a “proposed price of $5,000.” The form concluded, “This proposal will not become a contract until signed by you [developer] and then returned to and signed by me [driller].” The developer signed the form and returned it to driller, who neglected to sign it but promptly began drilling the well at the proposed site on developer’s project. After drilling for two days, driller told developer during one of developer’s daily visits that he would not finish unless developer agreed to pay twice the price recited in the written proposal. The developer refused, driller quit, and developer hired a different driller to drill the well to completion for a price of $7,500. In an action by developer against driller for damages, which of the following is the probable decision?
column4: The developer wins, because his signing of driller’s form constituted an acceptance of an offer by driller.
column5: The developer wins, because driller’s commencement of performance constituted an acceptance by driller of an offer by developer and an implied promise by driller to complete the well.
column6: The driller wins, because he never signed the proposal as required by its terms.
column7: The driller wins, because his commencement of performance merely prevented developer from revoking his offer, made on a form supplied by driller, and did not obligate driller to complete the well.

column3: Plaintiff sued Defendant in an automobile accident case brought under diversity jurisdiction in Federal District Court, claiming $50,000 in medical expenses, $20,000 in lost wages, and $100,000 in general damages for pain and suffering. After a trial before the District Court Judge sitting without a jury, the Judge found for Plaintiff, and awarded Plaintiff $50,000 in medical expenses, $20,000 in lost wages, and $250,000 in general damages for pain and suffering. Defendant appeals the award of general damages. On appeal, the Court of Appeal should:
column4: Affirm the judgment.
column5: Affirm the judgment, if the evidence supports the award of $250,000 for general damages.
column6: Reverse the judgment even if the evidence supports the award of $250,000 for general damages.
column7: Reverse the judgment unless, before the trial began, Plaintiff first moved to amend his Complaint to increase his claim for general damages.

column3: A man joined a neighborhood gang. At a gang meeting, as part of the initiation process, the leader ordered the man to kill a member of a rival gang. The man refused, saying he no longer wanted to be part of the group. The leader, with the approval of the other members, told the man that he had become too involved with the gang to quit and that they would kill him if he did not accomplish the murder of the rival gang member. The next day the man shot the rival gang member to death while the rival gang member was sitting on his motorcycle outside a restaurant. The man is charged with first-degree murder. First-degree murder is defined in the jurisdiction as the intentional premeditated killing of another. Second-degree murder is all other murder at common law. If the man killed the rival gang member because of the threat to his own life, the man should be found
column4: not guilty, because of the defense of duress.
column5: not guilty, because of the defense of necessity.
column6: guilty of first-degree murder.
column7: guilty of second-degree murder.

column3: An owner and a planner signed a detailed writing in which the planner, a landscape architect, agreed to landscape and replant the owner’s residential property in accordance with a design prepared by the planner and incorporated in the writing. The owner agreed to pay $10,000 for the work upon its completion. The owner’s spouse was not a party to the agreement, and had no ownership interest in the premises. Shortly before the agreement was signed, the owner and the planner orally agreed that the writing would not become binding on either party unless the owner’s spouse should approve the landscaping design. If the owner’s spouse disapproves the design and the owner refuses to allow the planner to proceed with the work, is evidence of the oral agreement admissible in the planner’s action against the owner for breach of contract?
column4: Yes, because the oral agreement required approval by a third party.
column5: Yes, because the evidence shows that the writing was intended to take effect only if approval occurred.
column6: No, because the parol evidence rule bars evidence of a prior oral agreement even if the latter is consistent with the terms of a partial integration.
column7: No, because the prior oral agreement contradicted the writing by making the parties’ duties conditional.

column3: A well-established paper mill and a logging company signed a written contract in which the mill agreed to buy from the company all the logs the mill would need for one year. The company was unable to keep up with the mill's needs, and its log deliveries fell short by 10% to 15% in each of the four quarters of the year. The mill paid the company on time for all delivered logs. The mill paid an attorney $2,000 for advice concerning its options in enforcing the contract. It paid a broker a reasonable fee of $5,000 to find additional logs to make up for the company's shortfall. The mill also incurred reasonable costs of $25,000 to transport the additional logs to its facility. Despite the mill's efforts to mitigate damages, it sustained $200,000 in losses because of the company's failure to timely deliver enough logs. The mill has sued the company for breach of contract. If the court finds for the mill, how much should it award in damages?

On the basis of scientific studies showing a causal relationship between the consumption of "red meat" (principally beef) and certain forms of cancer, a federal statute prohibits all commercial advertising of red meat products. The statute does not, however, restrict the sale of red meat products. Producers of red meat have challenged the statute as a violation of their free speech rights protected by the First Amendment. Is the court likely to find the statute constitutional?
column4: No, because it does not serve a substantial government interest.
column5: No, because it is more extensive than necessary to serve the government interest in preventing certain cancers.
column6: Yes, because it does not affect speech protected by the First Amendment.
column7: Yes, because it serves a legitimate government interest in protecting public health.

column3: A man and a woman owned a large tract of land, in fee simple as joint tenants with rights of survivorship. While the woman was on an extended safari in Kenya, the man learned that there were very valuable coal deposits within the tract, but he made no attempt to inform the woman. Thereupon, the man conveyed his interest in the tract to his wife, who immediately reconveyed that interest to the man. The common-law joint tenancy is unmodified by statute. Shortly thereafter, the man was killed in an automobile accident. His will, which was duly probated, specifically devised his one-half interest in the tract to the wife. The woman then returned from Kenya and learned what had happened. The woman brought an appropriate action against the wife, who claimed a one-half interest in the tract, seeking a declaratory judgment that she (the woman) was the sole owner of the tract. In this action, who should prevail?
column4: The wife, because the man and the woman were tenants in common at the time of the man’s death.
column5: The wife, because the man’s will severed the joint tenancy.
column6: The woman, because the joint tenancy was reestablished by the wife’s reconveyance to the man.
column7: The woman, because the man breached his fiduciary duty as her joint tenant.

column3: A man operates a residential rehabilitation center for emotionally disturbed and ungovernable children who have been committed to his custody by their parents or by juvenile authorities. The center's purpose is to modify the behavior of the children through a teaching program carried out in a family-like environment. Though the children are not permitted to leave the center without his permission, there are no bars or guards to prevent them from doing so. It has been held in the state where the center is located that persons having custody of children have the same duties and responsibilities that they would have if they were the parents of the children. A boy, aged 12, who had been in the man’s custody for six months, left the center without permission. The man became aware of the boy's absence almost immediately, but made no attempt to locate him or secure his return, though reports reached him that the boy had been seen in the vicinity. Thirty-six hours after the boy left the center, he committed a brutal assault upon a five-year-old child, causing the child to suffer extensive permanent injury. If an action is brought against the man on behalf of the child to recover damages for the child's injuries, will the child prevail?
column4: No, because parents are not personally liable for their child's intentional torts;
column5: Yes, if the boy was old enough to be liable for battery;
column6: Yes, because the boy was in the man's custody;
column7: No, unless the man knew or had reason to know that the boy had a propensity to attack younger children.

column3: Defendant was prosecuted for homicide. He testified that he shot in self-defense. In rebuttal, Police Officer testified that he came to the scene in response to a telephone call from Defendant. Police Officer offers to testify that he asked, "What is the problem here, sir?" and Defendant replied, "I was cleaning my gun and it went off accidentally." The Police Officer’s testimony is:
column4: admissible, as an excited utterance.
column5: admissible, to impeach Defendant and as evidence that he did not act in self- defense.
column6: inadmissible, because of Defendant's privilege against self-incrimination.
column7: inadmissible, because it tends to exculpate without corroboration.

column3: A corporation operates restaurants in 45 states. It is incorporated in Wyoming, with its corporate headquarters in Montana. Plaintiff became ill from eating a tainted blueberry pie at corporation’s restaurant in Pocatello, Idaho. This particular restaurant had only been open six months, and was the only corporation restaurant in Idaho. Plaintiff, an Idaho resident, sues corporation on theories of battery and negligence in Idaho Federal Court. Corporation specially appears on a motion to dismiss Plaintiff’s suit for lack of jurisdiction. The court will probably rule that the motion should be:
column4: Denied, because the corporation’s special appearance will be deemed consent to personal jurisdiction.
column5: Denied, because the operation of a restaurant in Pocatello, Idaho for six months constituted purposeful availment of the benefits of the state of Idaho, and it was foreseeable that the corporation could be haled into court in Idaho.
column6: Granted, because the operation of one restaurant for only six months did not constitute sufficient minimum contacts within the state of Idaho so as to comport with traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.
column7: Granted, because the Federal Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction.

column3: At the time of his death last week, a man owned a small farm. By his duly probated will, drawn five years ago, the man did the following: (1)gave “all the rest, residue and remainder of my Estate, both real and personal, to my friend the farmer.” At his death, the man was survived by the artist, the chef, and a soldier (the man’s son and sole heir), and the farmer. The baker had died a week before the man. Title to the farm is now in
column4: Artist for life, remainder to Chef.
column5: Chef, in fee simple.
column6: Soldier, in fee simple.
column7: Farmer, in fee simple.

column3: Plaintiff sues two defendants in Federal Court, alleging that each acted as joint tortfeasors in causing Plaintiff’s injury, and that each is jointly and severally liable. The two defendants claim that a third man is also a joint tortfeasor, and would be jointly and severally liable, and they move to dismiss Plaintiff’s suit for failing to join the third man. Their motion should be:
column4: Denied, because a joint tortfeasor subject to joint and several liability is not necessary for just adjudication.
column5: Denied, if the two defendants together have sufficient insurance and assets to pay for Plaintiff’s damages.
column6: Granted, because the third man is a necessary and indispensable party.
column7: Granted, because otherwise the third man will not be able to adequately defend his interests.

column3: An expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings contracted in a signed writing to lift and emplace certain air-conditioning equipment atop a building. An exculpatory clause in the contract provided that the expert would not be liable for any physical damage to the building occurring during installation of the air-conditioning equipment. There was also a clause providing for per diem damages if the expert did not complete performance by a specified date and a clause providing that “time is of the essence.” Another clause provided that any subsequent agreement for extra work under the contract must be in writing and signed by both parties. With ample time remaining under the contract for commencement and completion of his performance, the expert notified the building owner that he was selling his business to a helicopter company, who was equally expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings, and that the helicopter company had agreed to “take over the expert-building owner contract.” Assume that building owner orally agreed with the expert to accept the helicopter company’s services and that the helicopter company performed on time but negligently installed the wrong air-conditioning equipment. Will the building owner succeed in an action against expert for damages for breach of contract?
column4: Yes, because building owner did not agree to release expert from liability under the contract.
column5: Yes, because building owner received no consideration for the substitution of helicopter company for expert.
column6: No, because by accepting the substitution of helicopter company for expert, building owner effected a novation, and expert was thereby discharged of his duties under the contract.
column7: No, because the liquidated-damage clause in the contract provided only for damages caused by delay in performance.

column3: A man owned a tract in fee simple of record on January 10. On that day, a woman loaned the man $50,000 and the man mortgaged the land to the woman as security for the loan. The mortgage was recorded on January 18. The man conveyed the land to a bookseller for a valuable consideration on January 11. The woman did not know of this, nor did the bookseller know of the mortgage to the woman, until both discovered the facts on January 23, the day on which the bookseller recorded the man’s deed. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: “No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record.” There is no provision for a period of grace and there is no other relevant statutory provision. The woman sued the bookseller to establish that her mortgage was good against the tract. The court should decide for
column4: the bookseller, because he paid valuable consideration without notice before the woman recorded her mortgage.
column5: the bookseller, because the woman’s delay in recording means that she is estopped from asserting her priority in time.
column6: The woman, because the bookseller did not record his deed before her mortgage was recorded.
column7: The woman, because after the mortgage to her, the man’s deed to the bookseller was necessarily subject to her mortgage.

column2: Real Property,  Easements,  Covenants and Servitudes
column3: A man owned two adjacent parcels, Blackacre and Whiteacre. Blackacre fronts on a poor unpaved road, while Whiteacre fronts on Route 20, a paved major highway. Fifteen years ago, the man conveyed to his son Blackacre “together with a right-of-way 25 feet wide over the east side of Whiteacre to Route 20.” At that time, Blackacre was improved with a ten-unit motel. Ten years ago, the man died. His will devised Whiteacre “to my son for life, remainder to my daughter.” Five years ago, the son executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Blackacre and Whiteacre to a developer in fee simple. The developer then enlarged the motel to 12 units. Six months ago, the son died and the daughter took possession of Whiteacre. She brought an appropriate action to enjoin the developer from using the right-of-way. In this action, who should prevail?
column4: The daughter, because merger extinguished the easement.
column5: The daughter, because the developer has overburdened the easement.
column6: The developer, because he has an easement by necessity.
column7: The developer, because he has the easement granted by the man to his son.

column3: A defendant who is an accountant has been charged with fraud for allegedly helping a client file false income tax returns by shifting substantial medical expenses from one year to another. The defendant has pleaded not guilty, claiming that he made an honest mistake as to the date the expenses were paid. At trial, the prosecutor offers evidence of the defendant's involvement in an earlier scheme to help a different client falsify tax returns in the same way. Is the evidence of the defendant's involvement in the earlier scheme admissible?
column4: No, because it is impermissible character evidence.
column5: No, because it is not relevant to the issues in this case.
column6: Yes, to show absence of mistake.
column7: Yes, to show the defendant's propensity to commit the crime.

column3: A retailer brought a federal diversity action against a wholesaler, alleging breach of contract and fraudulent misrepresentation. After the parties presented their evidence at trial, the court instructed the jury on the law. Neither party filed a motion for judgment as a matter of law before the case went to the jury. The jury found for the retailer on both claims. After the court entered judgment on the verdict, the wholesaler moved for a new trial and for judgment as a matter of law, arguing that the evidence was insufficient to support the jury verdict on either claim. The court acknowledged that there had been problems with some of the evidence, but it denied the motions. The wholesaler appealed, challenging the sufficiency of the evidence. Should the appellate court consider the wholesaler's challenge?
column4: No, because a determination of the sufficiency of the evidence is solely within the jury's province.
column5: No, because the wholesaler did not raise the sufficiency-of-the-evidence issue in a motion for judgment as a matter of law before the case went to the jury.
column6: Yes, because the challenge was raised and ruled on by the trial court before the wholesaler filed the appeal.
column7: Yes, because, as the trial court acknowledged, the wholesaler has strong arguments on the challenge.

column3: A man decided to destroy an old warehouse that he owned because the taxes on the structure exceeded the income that he could receive from it. He crept into the building in the middle of the night with a can of gasoline and a fuse and set the fuse timer for 30 minutes. He then left the building. The fuse failed to ignite, and the building was not harmed. Arson is defined in the jurisdiction as “the intentional burning of any building or structure of another, without consent of the owner.” The man believed, however, that burning one’s own building was arson, having been so advised by his lawyer. Has the man committed attempted arson?
column4: Yes, because factual impossibility is no defense.
column5: Yes, because a mistake of law even on the advice of an attorney is no defense.
column6: No, because his mistake negated a necessary mental state.
column7: No, because even if his actions had every consequence he intended, they would not have constituted arson.

column3: A state criminal law prohibits the publication of any description of the details of the execution of any prisoner who is sentenced to death by the courts of the state. Although the law allows a specified number of reporters to observe an execution, only the prison warden's official statement that the prisoner was "executed as provided by law" at a certain time and date may be published. The purpose of the law is to protect the public, particularly children, from the details of executions. After a particular execution was mishandled, causing the prisoner to suffer, a newspaper in the state published a story describing the event in detail. The story was written by the newspaper's reporter, who was permitted to observe the execution but did not promise prison officials that he would report only the warden's official statement. A prosecutor subsequently filed charges against the newspaper for publishing the details of the execution in violation of the state law. Is this prosecution constitutional?
column4: No, because the prosecution seeks to punish the publication of lawfully obtained, truthful information about a matter of public significance, without adequate justification.
column5: No, because the reporter did not promise prison officials that he would report only the warden's official statement about the execution.
column6: Yes, because publication of the details of such events might cause psychological damage to some children.
column7: Yes, because the newspaper should have brought an action to test the validity of the law before publishing the reporter's story.

column3: After several well-publicized deaths caused by fires in products made from highly flammable fabrics, a State enacted a statute prohibiting "the manufacture or assembly of any product in this state which contains any fabric that has not been tested and approved for flame retardancy by Testing Company." Testing Company is a privately owned and operated business located in State. For many years, a fabric mill located in the State has had its fabric tested for flame retardancy by a different testing company located in another state. The different testing company is a reliable organization that uses a process for testing and approving fabrics for flame retardancy identical in all respects to that used by Testing Company. Because the fabric mill wishes to continue to have its fabric tested solely by the different testing company, the fabric mill files an action in state court challenging the constitutionality of the State statute as applied to its circumstances. In this suit, the court should hold the statute to be:
column4: constitutional, because it is reasonably related to the protection of the reputation of the fabric industry located in State.
column5: constitutional, because it is a legitimate means of protecting the safety of the public.
column6: unconstitutional, because it denies to the fabric mill the equal protection of the laws.
column7: unconstitutional, because it imposes an unreasonable burden on interstate commerce.

column3: Two boys were in the habit of playing practical jokes on each other on their respective birthdays. On one boy's birthday, the other boy sent him a cake containing an ingredient that the other boy knew had, in the past, made the one boy very ill. After the one boy had eaten a piece of the cake, he suffered severe stomach pains and had to be taken to the hospital by ambulance. On the way to the hospital, the ambulance driver suffered a heart attack, which caused the ambulance to swerve from the road and hit a tree. As a result of the collision, the one boy suffered a broken leg. In a suit by the one boy against the other boy to recover damages for the broken leg, the one boy will:
column4: prevail, because the other boy knew that the cake would be harmful or offensive to the one boy;
column5: prevail, only if the ambulance driver was negligent
column6: not prevail, because the other boy could not reasonably be expected to foresee injury to the one boy's leg;
column7: not prevail, because the ambulance driver's heart attack was a superseding cause of the broken leg.

column3: Defendant, charged with armed robbery of a store, denied that he was the person who had robbed the store. In presenting the state's case, the prosecutor seeks to introduce evidence that Defendant had robbed two other stores in the past year. This evidence is:
column4: admissible, to prove a pertinent trait of Defendant 's character and Defendant's action in conformity therewith.
column5: admissible, to prove Defendant's intent and identity.
column6: inadmissible, because character must be proved by reputation or opinion and may not be proved by specific acts.
column7: inadmissible, because its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.

column3: Twenty-five years ago, a seller conveyed Blackacre to a buyer by a warranty deed. The seller at that time also executed and delivered an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Whiteacre to the buyer. The seller thought she had title to Whiteacre but did not; therefore, no title passed by virtue of the Whiteacre deed. Whiteacre consisted of three acres of brushland adjoining the west boundary of Blackacre. The buyer has occasionally hunted rabbits on Whiteacre, but less often than annually. No one else came on Whiteacre except occasional rabbit hunters.Twenty years ago, the buyer planted a row of evergreens in the vicinity of the opposite (east) boundary of Blackacre and erected a fence just beyond the evergreens to the east. In fact both the trees and the fence were placed on Greenacre, owned by a neighbor, which bordered the east boundary of Blackacre. The buyer was unsure of the exact boundary, and placed the trees and the fence in order to establish his rights up to the fence. The fence is located ten feet within Greenacre.Now, the buyer has had his property surveyed and the title checked and has learned the facts. The period of time to acquire title by adverse possession is 15 years. The buyer consulted his lawyer, who properly advised that, in an appropriate action, the buyer would probably obtain title to
column4: Whiteacre but not to the ten-foot strip of Greenacre.
column5: the ten-foot strip of Greenacre but not to Whiteacre.
column6: both Whiteacre and the ten-foot strip of Greenacre.
column7: neither Whiteacre nor the ten-foot strip of Greenacre.

column3: The aged mother of two adults, a son and daughter, wished to employ a live-in companion so that she might continue to live in her own home. The mother, however, had only enough income to pay one-half of the companion’s $2,000 monthly salary. Learning of their mother’s plight, the son and daughter agreed with each other in a signed writing that on the last day of January and each succeeding month during their mother’s lifetime, each would give the mother $500. The mother then hired the companion.Both adult children made the agreed payments in January, February and March. In April, however, the son refused to make any payments and notified the daughter and the mother that he would make no further payments. Will the mother succeed in an action for $500 brought against the son after April 30?
column4: Yes, because by making his first three payments, the son confirmed his intent to contract.
column5: Yes, because the mother is an intended beneficiary of a contract between the son and daughter.
column6: No, because a parent cannot sue her child for breach of a promise for support.
column7: No, because the son and daughter intended their payments to the mother to be gifts.

column3: A toy collector had purchased 10 antique toys over the last several years and had had them restored by an expert in toy restoration. On June l, the collector sent the 11th antique toy to the expert with a signed note that read: "Here is another toy for you to restore. As with all prior jobs, I will pay $500 for the work, but no more." On June 4, after receipt of the collector's June 1 note and the toy, the expert began restoring the toy. On June 6, the collector unexpectedly died. On June 7, unaware of the collector's death, the expert sent the collector a note that stated that the restoration work had begun on June 4. The following day, the expert learned of the collector's death.Does a contract exist that binds the expert and the collector's estate?
column4: No, because the collector died before the expert sent the June 7 note.
column5: No, because the offer lapsed when the collector died.
column6: Yes, because the expert sent the June 7 note before learning of the collector's death.
column7: Yes, because the offer was accepted before the collector's death.

column3: An owner of land contracted to sell it to a buyer for $100,000, its fair market value at that time. After an unanticipated zoning change increased the land's fair market value to $150,000 during the executory period, the owner refused to close. Wishing to avoid a lawsuit, the buyer assigned the contract (which the contract did not forbid) in an arm's-length transaction to an investor, who is experienced in buying and selling real estate. The investor paid the buyer $25,000. The investor knew of the owner's refusal to close, and the owner continued to refuse to close despite the investor's demands that he do so. The investor has sued the owner for specific performance. Who will likely prevail?
column4: The investor, because an assignee of the original party purchaser in a real estate contract is entitled to specific performance under these circumstances.
column5: The investor, because she has elected to waive the owner's lack of marketable title caused by the zoning change.
column6: The owner, because the investor is not a bona fide assignee without notice, and thus does not have clean hands.
column7: The owner, because the investor, who is experienced in buying and selling real estate, is entitled to money damages but not to specific performance.

column3: Suspecting that a man had slain his wife, police detectives persuaded one of the man’s employees to remove a drinking glass from the man’s office so that it could be used for fingerprint comparisons with a knife found near the body. The fingerprints matched. The prosecutor announced that he would present comparisons and evidence to the grand jury. The man’s lawyer immediately filed a motion to suppress the evidence of the fingerprint comparisons to bar its consideration by the grand jury, contending that the evidence was illegally acquired.The motion should be
column4: granted, because, if there was no probable cause, the grand jury should not consider the evidence.
column5: granted, because the employee was acting as a police agent and his seizure of the glass without a warrant was unconstitutional.
column6: denied, because motions based on the exclusionary rule are premature in grand jury proceedings.
column7: denied, because the glass was removed from Scott’s possession by a private citizen and not a police officer.

column3: If the man brings an action, based on negligence, against the grocery store, the store's best defense will be that:
column4: a store owes no duty to its customers to control the use of its shopping carts
column6: a store owes no duty to its customers to control the conduct of other customers
column8: any negligence of the store was not the proximate cause of the man's injury
column10: a supervised child pushing a cart does not pose an unreasonable risk to other customers.

column3: If the man brings an action, based on negligence, against the girl's mother, will the man prevail?
column4: Yes, if the girl was negligent;
column5: Yes, because the girl's mother is responsible for any harm caused by the girl;
column6: Yes, because the girl's mother assumed the risk of her child's actions;
column7: Yes, if the girl's mother did not adequately supervise the girl's actions.

column3: If the man brings an action, based on negligence, against the girl, the girl's best argument in defense would be that:
column4: The girl exercised care commensurate with her age, intelligence, and experience;
column5: The girl is not subject to tort liability
column7: The girl was subject to parental supervision
column9: The man assumed the risk that the girl might hit him with the cart.

column3: A man entered into a valid written contract to sell a large tract of land to a woman. At that time, the land was owned by the man’s father; the man had no title to the land and was not the agent of his father.After the contract was executed and before the scheduled closing date, the father died intestate, leaving the man as his sole heir. Shortly thereafter, the man received an offer for the land that was substantially higher than the purchase price in the contract with the woman.
