The man refused to close with the woman although she was ready, willing, and able to close pursuant to the contract.The woman brought an appropriate action for specific performance against the man. In that action, the woman should be awarded
column4: nothing, because the man had no authority to enter into the contract with the woman.
column5: nothing, because the doctrine of after-acquired title does not apply to executor contracts.
column6: judgment for specific performance, because the man acquired title prior to the scheduled closing.
column7: judgment for specific performance, to prevent unjust enrichment of the man.

column3: A man operates a collection agency. He was trying to collect a $400 bill for medical services rendered to a woman by her doctor. The man went to the woman's house and when her mother answered the door, the man told the mother he was there to collect a bill owed by the woman. The woman’s mother told the man that because of her illness, the woman had been unemployed for six months, that she was still ill and unable to work, and that she would pay the bill as soon as she could. The man, in a loud voice, demanded to see the woman and said that if he did not receive payment immediately, he would file a criminal complaint charging her with fraud. The woman, hearing the conversation, came to the door. The man, in a loud voice, repeated his demand for immediate payment and his threat to use criminal process. If the woman asserts a claim against the man, based on infliction of emotional distress, will the woman prevail?
column4: Yes, if the woman suffered severe emotional distress as a result of the man's conduct;
column5: Yes, unless the bill for medical services was valid and past due;
column6: No, unless the woman suffered physical harm as a result of the man's conduct;
column7: No, if the man's conduct created no risk of physical harm to the woman.

column3: Public schools in a State are financed, in large part, by revenue derived from real estate taxes imposed by each school district on the taxable real property located in that district. Public schools also receive other revenue from private gifts, federal grants, student fees, and local sales taxes. For many years, State has distributed additional funds, which come from the state treasury, to local school districts in order to equalize the funds available on a per-student basis for each public school district. These additional funds are distributed on the basis of a state statutory formula that considers only the number of students in each public school district and the real estate tax revenue raised by that district. The formula does not consider other revenue received by a school district from different sources. The school boards of two school districts, together with parents and schoolchildren in those districts, bring suit in federal court to enjoin the state from allocating the additional funds from the state treasury to individual districts pursuant to this formula. They allege that the failure of the State, in allocating this additional money, to take into account a school district's sources of revenue other than revenue derived from taxes levied on real estate located there violates the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The complaint does not allege that the allocation of the additional state funds based on the current statutory formula has resulted in a failure to provide minimally adequate education to any child. Which of the following best describes the appropriate standard by which the court should review the constitutionality of the state statutory funding formula?
column4: Because classifications based on wealth are inherently suspect, the state must demonstrate that the statutory formula is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest.
column5: Because the statutory funding formula burdens the fundamental right to education, the state must demonstrate that the formula is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest.
column6: Because no fundamental right or suspect classification is implicated in this case, the plaintiffs must demonstrate that the funding allocation formula bears no rational relationship to any legitimate state interest.
column7: Because the funding formula inevitably leads to disparities among the school districts in their levels of total funding, the plaintiffs must only demonstrate that the funding formula is not substantially related to the furtherance of an important state interest.

column3: A hot-air balloon touring company operated near a golf course. The company's property was separated from the golf course by a fence on which the company had posted signs warning people not to enter the property because of the dangers of balloons landing. A golfer on the golf course hit an errant shot onto the company's property, ignored the warning signs, and jumped over the fence to retrieve her golf ball. At about the same time, one of the company's balloons experienced mechanical problems and had to make an emergency landing to avoid crashing. The balloon, which was out of control when it landed, struck the golfer and injured her. The jurisdiction has decided that hot-air ballooning is an abnormally dangerous activity. In an action by the golfer against the company, does the company have any affirmative defenses?
column4: No, because the balloon was out of control when it struck the golfer.
column5: No, because the company was engaged in an abnormally dangerous activity.
column6: Yes, because the balloon landed to avoid crashing.
column7: Yes, because the golfer assumed the risk by coming onto the company's property.

column3: A man and a woman were partners in an automobile leasing agency. For some time, the man had been embezzling money from the agency. The woman became suspicious and told the man that she wanted to engage an accounting firm to audit the agency's books. In a panic to prevent the audit and avoid being discovered, the man decided to have the woman killed. He contacted a professional killer and hired him to kill the woman for $10,000. A short time later, the woman died in a car crash arranged by the killer. In addition to embezzlement, of what crime or crimes may the man properly be convicted?
column4: Conspiracy and murder.
column5: Murder.
column6: Solicitation and conspiracy.
column7: Solicitation, conspiracy, and murder.

column3: Two men are involved in a dispute concerning a contract. On February 1, Plaintiff serves Defendant with a complaint seeking specific performance of the contract. On February 8, Defendant files an answer, denying that it breached the contract and counterclaiming against Plaintiff for damages, alleging that Plaintiff breached the contract. Defendant served his answer on February 15th. On February 19th, Plaintiff filed and served his reply, denying liability on the counterclaim. In his reply, Plaintiff also requested a jury trial. The court should:
column4: Deny the request for a jury trial because the request was more than 14 days after he filed his complaint and thus untimely.
column5: Deny the request because Plaintiff does not have an unqualified right to a jury trial for his cause of action.
column6: Grant the request because Plaintiff’s request was made less than 14 days after receiving Defendant's answer and counterclaim.
column7: Grant the request as a matter of law because Defendant filed a counterclaim.

column3: A company owns and operates a beachfront hotel. Under a contract with City to restore a public beach, a contractor placed a large and unavoidably dangerous stone-crushing machine on City land near the company's hotel. The machine creates a continuous and intense noise that is so disturbing to the hotel guests that they have canceled their hotel reservations in large numbers, resulting in a substantial loss to the company.The company's best chance to recover damages for its financial losses from the contractor is under the theory that the operation of the stone-crushing machine constitutes:
column4: an abnormally dangerous activity
column6: a private nuisance

column3: A state law imposes penalties for "any public statement containing false or misleading information about a service or product." An airline falsely claimed in an advertisement that its competitor had an inferior safety record. The claim was based on erroneous information, found on the website of a nonprofit consumer advocacy group, that the airline assumed to be true. The airline was charged under the state law for making a false statement. No federal statute applies.Which of the following best supports the airline in a defense based on the First Amendment?
column4: Its statement about the safety record was made without malice.
column5: Its statement about the safety record was protected noncommercial speech.
column6: The state law is a prior restraint.
column7: The state law is overbroad.

column3: Plaintiff Corporation sued Defendant for ten fuel oil deliveries not paid for. Don denied that the deliveries were made. At trial, Plaintiff calls its office manager to testify that Plaintiff’s employees always record each delivery in duplicate, give one copy to the customer, and place the other copy in Plaintiff 's files; that he (the office manager) is the custodian of those files; and that his examination of the files before coming to court revealed that the ten deliveries were made.The office manager's testimony that the invoices show ten deliveries is:
column4: admissible, because it is based on regularly kept business records.
column5: admissible, because the office manager has first¬hand knowledge of the contents of the records.
column6: inadmissible, because the records must be produced in order to prove their contents.
column7: inadmissible, because the records are self-serving.

column3: A man entered the police station and announced that he wanted to confess to a murder. The police advised the man of the Miranda warnings, and the man signed a written waiver. The man described the murder in detail and pinpointed the location where a murder victim had been found a few weeks before. Later, a court-appointed psychiatrist determined that the man was suffering from a serious mental illness that interfered with his ability to make rational choices and to understand his rights and that the psychosis had induced his confession.The man’s confession is
column4: admissible, because there was no coercive police conduct in obtaining the man’s statement.
column5: admissible, because the man was not in custody.
column6: inadmissible, because the man’s confession was a product of his mental illness and was therefore involuntary.
column7: inadmissible, because under these circumstances, there was no valid waiver of Miranda warnings.

column2: Real Property,  Mortgages,  Foreclosure,  and Security
column3: A man borrowed money from a lender and mortgaged land that he owned to secure repayment of the loan. Before he had completely repaid the loan, the man conveyed the land to an investor, who expressly assumed the loan. The note and mortgage did not contain a due-on-sale clause.After the investor had made several payments on the loan, she defaulted on two payments. The lender notified the man and the investor of its intention to accelerate the loan pursuant to the terms of the note and mortgage unless the default was cured within 60 days. When neither the man nor the investor made the required payment, the lender accelerated the loan and initiated foreclosure proceedings, naming both the man and the investor as party defendants. The foreclosure sale resulted in a deficiency. The lender has sought a deficiency judgment against only the man, because the investor has become insolvent in the meantime.Will the court likely find the man liable for the deficiency?
column4: No, because the investor's express assumption of the loan released the man from liability.
column5: No, because the lender must first seek to obtain a deficiency judgment against the investor.
column6: Yes, because even after the assumption, the man remains liable as a surety of the investor in the absence of a release from the lender.
column7: Yes, because the note and mortgage did not contain a due-on-sale clause.

column3: While a woman was riding her horse on what she thought was a public path, the owner of a house next to the path approached her, shaking a stick and shouting, "Get off my property." Unknown to the woman, the path on which she was riding crossed the private property of the shouting owner. When the woman explained that she thought the path was a public trail, the owner cursed her, approached the woman's horse, and struck the horse with the stick. As a result of the blow, the horse reared, causing the woman to fear that she would fall. However, the woman managed to stay on the horse, and then departed. Neither the woman nor the horse suffered bodily harm.If the woman brings an action for damages against the owner, the result should be for:
column4: The woman, for trespass to her chattel property;
column5: The woman, for battery and assault
column6: The owner, because the woman suffered no physical harm;
column7: The owner, because he was privileged to exclude trespassers from his property.

column3: Five years ago, a woman acquired a plot of land, improved with a 15-year-old dwelling. This year the woman listed the land for sale with a licensed real estate broker. The woman informed the broker of several defects in the house that were not readily discoverable by a reasonable inspection, including a leaky basement, an inadequate water supply, and a roof that leaked. A man responded to the broker’s advertisement, was taken by the broker to view the land, and decided to buy it. The broker saw to it that the contract specified the property to be “as is” but neither the broker nor the woman pointed out the defects to the man, who did not ask about the condition of the dwelling. After closing and taking possession, the man discovered the defects, had them repaired, and demanded that the woman reimburse him for the cost of the repairs. The woman refused and the man brought an appropriate action against the woman for damages.If the woman wins, it will be because
column4: The woman fulfilled the duty to disclose defects by disclosure to the broker
column5: the contract’s “as is” provision controls the rights of the parties.
column6: The broker became the agent of both the man and the woman and thus knowledge of the defects was imputed to the man.
column7: the seller of a used dwelling that has been viewed by the buyer has no responsibility toward the buyer.

column3: In which of the following situations would a court applying common-law doctrine be most likely to convict a man of the crime charged, despite the man’s mistake?
column4: The man was charged with bigamy. He married his neighbor four years after her husband was reported missing at sea. The rescued husband returns alive. A state statute provides that a person is presumed dead after five years of unexplained absence. The man believed the statutory period was three years.
column5: The man was charged with murder after he shot and killed a man who had extorted money from him. The man mistakenly thought the victim had raised his hand to shoot, when, in fact, the victim was shaking his fist at the man to frighten him.
column6: The man was charged with assault with intent to rape a woman who he mistakenly believed had agreed to have sexual intercourse with him.
column7: The man was charged with burglary. He had broken into an office where he once worked and had taken a typewriter that he erroneously believed had been given to him before he was fired.

column3: A man owed a lender $1,000, plus interest at 8% until paid, on a long-overdue promissory note, collection of which would become barred by the statute of limitations on June 30. On the preceding April 1, the man and the lender both signed a writing in which the man promised to pay the note in full on the following December 31, plus interest at 8% until that date, and the lender promised not to sue on the note in the meantime. The lender, having received some advice from his nonlawyer brother-in-law, became concerned about the legal effect of the April 1 agreement. On May 1, acting pro se as permitted by the rules of the local small claims court, he filed suit to collect the note.Assuming there is no controlling statute, is the April 1 agreement an effective defense for Spender?
column4: Yes, because the man’s promise to pay interest until December 31 was consideration for the lender’s promise not to sue.
column5: Yes, because the law creates a presumption that the man relied on the lender’s promise not to sue.
column6: No, because there was no consideration for the lender’s promise not to sue, in that the man was already obligated to pay $1,000 plus interest at 8% until the payment date.
column7: No, because the man’s April 1 promise is enforceable with or without consideration.

column3: A buyer sent a signed letter to a seller that stated: "Ship 100 boxes of nails at $3 per box, the price quoted in your circular." The seller mailed the buyer a signed fom acknowledgment that agreed to the buyer's terms and stated on the reverse side: "Disputes regarding quality shall be arbitrated." The buyer did not reply to the seller's acknowledgment, and the seller shipped the nails. When the buyer received the nails, it found their quality to be unsatisfactory and sued the seller for breach of warranty. The seller has asked an attorney whether the parties' contract requires arbitration of the buyer's claim.What is the best advice the attorney can provide?
column4: A contract was formed pursuant to conduct when the buyer received the nails, and a court would exclude the arbitration provision from the contract.
column5: A contract was formed when the seller mailed its acknowledgment, and the arbitration term became part of the contract.
column6: A contract was formed when the seller mailed its acknowledgment, and the court must decide whether the arbitration term should be excluded as a material alteration of the contract.
column7: No contract exists, because the arbitration term in the seller's acknowledgment created a counteroffer that the buyer never accepted.

column3: A doctor who was licensed to practice medicine in a particular state was convicted in state court of improperly distributing specified drugs by writing prescriptions for fictitious persons. Under state law, such an abuse of the prescription-writing privilege requires revocation of a doctor's license. After it received an official notification of the doctor's conviction, the state medical board revoked the doctor's license without affording the doctor any opportunity for a hearing.The doctor has sued the board in state court to set aside the revocation, alleging deprivation of property without due process of law because the board did not provide an opportunity for a trial-type hearing before revoking the license. The doctor does not deny the conviction or the factual basis for it.Which of the following is the strongest argument in support of the state medical board?
column4: A doctor's license to practice is a privilege, not a right, and therefore is not property within the meaning of the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
column5: Due process requires a balancing of interests, and the state's interest in preventing drug abuse outweighs the doctor's interest in the particular procedure followed in the disciplinary proceeding.
column6: The adjudicative facts necessary to revoke the doctor's license were determined in the criminal trial, and therefore due process does not require any further trial-type hearing.
column7: The licensing board was required to summarily revoke the doctor's license because Article IV, Section 1, of the Constitution requires the licensing board to give full faith and credit to the doctor's criminal conviction.

column3: While driving his car, a man sustained injuries in a three-car collision. The man sued the drivers of the other two cars, a woman and a teen-ager, and each defendant cross-claimed against the other for contribution. The jurisdiction has adopted a rule of pure comparative negligence and allows contribution based upon proportionate fault. The rule of joint and several liability has been retained.The jury has found that the man sustained damages in the amount of $100,000, and apportioned the causal negligence of the parties as follows: the man 40%, the woman 30%, and the teen-ager 30%.How much, if anything, can the man collect from the woman, and how much, if anything, can the woman then collect from the teen-ager in contribution?
column4: Nothing, and then the woman can collect nothing from the teen-ager;
column5: $30,000, and then the woman can collect nothing from the teen-ager;
column6: $40,000, and then the woman can collect $10,000 from the teen-ager;
column7: $60,000, and then the woman can collect $30,000 from the teen-ager.

column3: A man and his adult daughter encountered an old family friend on the street. The daughter said to the friend, “How about lending me $1,000 to buy a used car? I’ll pay you back with interest one year from today.” The man added, “And if she doesn’t pay it back as promised, I will.” The friend thereupon wrote out and handed to the daughter his personal check, payable to her, for $1,000, and the daughter subsequently used the funds to buy a used car. When the debt became due, both the daughter and the man refused to repay it, or any part of it.In an action by the friend against the man to recover $1,000 plus interest, which of the following statements would summarize the man’s best defense?
column4: He received no consideration for his conditional promise to the friend.
column5: His conditional promise to the friend was not to be performed in less than a year from the time it was made.
column6: (LLLL) His conditional promise to the friend was not made for the primary purpose of benefitting himself (the man).
column7: The loan by the friend was made without any agreement concerning the applicable interest rate.

column3: A man and a woman owned a plot of land as joint tenants, upon which was situated a two-family house. The man lived in one of the two apartments and rented the other apartment to a tenant. The man got in a fight with the tenant and injured him. The tenant obtained and properly filed a judgment for $10,000 against the man.The statute in the jurisdiction reads: Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered.The woman, who lived in a distant city, knew nothing of the tenant’s judgment. Before the tenant took any further action, the man died. The common-law joint tenancy is unmodified by statute.The woman then learned the facts and brought an appropriate action against the tenant to quiet title to the land.The court should hold that the tenant has
column4: a lien against the whole of the land, because he was a tenant of both the man and the woman at the time of the judgment.
column5: a lien against the man’s undivided one-half interest in the land, because his judgment was filed prior to the man’s death.
column6: no lien, because the woman had no actual notice of the tenant’s judgment until after the man’s death.
column7: no lien, because the man’s death terminated the interest to which the tenant’s lien attached.

column3: In litigation on a federal claim, Plaintiff had the burden of proving that Defendant received a notice. Plaintiff relied on the presumption of receipt by offering evidence that the notice was addressed to Defendant, properly stamped, and mailed. Defendant, on the other hand, testified that she never received the notice.Which of the following is correct?
column4: The jury must find that the notice was received.
column5: The jury may find that the notice was received.
column6: The burden shifts to Defendant to persuade the jury of nonreceipt.
column7: The jury must find that the notice was not received, because the presumption has been rebutted and there is uncontradicted evidence of nonreceipt.

column3: In a medical malpractice suit by Plaintiff against Doctor, Plaintiff seeks to introduce a properly authenticated photocopy of Plaintiff 's hospital chart. The chart contained a notation made by a medical resident that an aortic clamp had broken during Plaintiff 's surgery. The resident made the notation in the regular course of practice, but had no personal knowledge of the operation, and cannot remember which of the operating physicians gave him the information.The document is:
column4: admissible as a record of regularly conducted activity.
column5: admissible as recorded recollection.
column6: inadmissible as a violation of the best evidence rule.
column7: inadmissible, because it is hearsay within hearsay.

column3: Plaintiff sued Defendant for damages for physical injuries allegedly caused by Defendant's violation of the federal civil rights law. The incident occurred wholly within the state but the case was tried in federal court. The state evidence code says, "The common-law privileges are preserved intact in this state."At trial, Davis called Plaintiff's physician, to testify to confidential statements made to him by Plaintiff in furtherance of medical treatment for the injuries allegedly caused by Defendant. Plaintiff objects, claiming a physician-patient privilege.The court should apply:
column4: state law and recognize the claim of privilege.
column5: federal law and recognize the claim of privilege.
column6: state law and reject the claim of privilege.
column7: federal law and reject the claim of privilege.

column3: A two-year-old girl became ill with meningitis. Her parents were members of a group that believed fervently that if they prayed enough, God would not permit their child to die. Accordingly, they did not seek medical aid for the girl and refused all offers of such aid. They prayed continuously. The girl died of the illness within a week.The parents are charged with murder in a common-law jurisdiction. Their best defense to the charge is that
column4: they did not intend to kill or to harm the girl.
column5: they were pursuing a constitutionally protected religious belief.
column6: The girl’s death was not proximately caused by their conduct.
column7: they neither premeditated nor deliberated.

column3: In a prosecution of Defendant for assault, a witness is called to testify that the victim had complained to the witness that Defendant was the assailant. The witness' testimony is most likely to be admitted if the witness is:
column4: a doctor, whom the victim consulted for treatment.
column5: a minister, whom the victim consulted for counseling.
column6: The victim's husband, whom she telephoned immediately after the event.
column7: a police officer, whom the victim called on instructions from her husband.

column3: A woman asked a man to lend her $1,000. The man replied that he would do so only if the woman’s father would guarantee the loan. At the woman’s request, her father mailed a signed letter to the man, “If you lend $1,000 to my daughter, I will repay it if she doesn’t.” On September 15, the man, having read the father’s letter, lent $1,000 to the woman, which the woman agreed to repay in installments of $100 plus accrued interest on the last day of each month beginning October 31. The father died on September 16. Later that same day, unaware of the father’s death, the man mailed a letter to the father advising that he had made the $1,000 loan to the woman on September 15.The woman did not pay the installments due on October 31, November 30, or December 31, and has informed the man that she will be unable to make repayments in the foreseeable future.On January 15, the man is entitled to a judgment against the woman for which of the following amounts?
column4: Nothing, because if he sues before the entire amount is due, he will be splitting his cause of action.
column5: $300 plus the accrued interest, because the woman’s breach was only a partial breach.
column6: $1,000 plus the accrued interest, because the woman’s unexcused failure to pay three installments is a material breach.
column7: $1,000 plus the accrued interest, because the failure to pay her debts as they come due indicates that the woman is insolvent and the man is thereby entitled to accelerate payment of the debt.

column3: A pedestrian domiciled in State A was crossing a street in State B when he was hit by a car driven by a citizen of a foreign country. Both the pedestrian and the driver suffered injuries.The pedestrian filed a negligence action against the driver in a federal district court in State B, seeking $100,000 in damages. The driver believes that the pedestrian was crossing the street illegally and is therefore responsible for the accident. The driver seeks an attorney's advice on how best to respond to the action. Assume that State B is a contributory negligence state.How should the attorney advise the driver to respond?
column4: File an answer raising the affirmative defense of contributory negligence and asserting a counterclaim for negligence, seeking damages for the driver's injuries.
column5: File an answer raising the affirmative defense of contributory negligence and move for judgment on the pleadings.
column6: Move to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, because the driver is not a citizen of State B.
column7: Move to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, because the driver is not a U.S. citizen.

column3: A plaintiff sued the manufacturer of his lawn mower, alleging that, as the result of a design defect, he was injured when the mower's blade flew off after striking a sprinkler head in the lawn.At trial, the manufacturer has called as an expert witness a product safety engineer, who testifies that the manufacturer retained him for a fee to test identical mowers and, if his opinion was helpful, to testify in the case. The expert then testifies that he did test the mowers, and that the blade, as designed and installed by the manufacturer, could not fly off in the manner claimed by the plaintiff. Assume that the expert has used a reliable method for reaching his conclusion.Should the court admit the expert's testimony?
column4: No, because it goes to an ultimate issue that only the jury can decide.
column5: No, because the manufacturer paid the expert to render a certain opinion, in violation of rules barring paid testimony.
column6: Yes, because expert testimony on such issues of causation is relevant and helpful to the jury.
column7: Yes, provided that the plaintiff had notice and an opportunity to participate in the testing process.

column3: A recent federal law assesses an excise tax of 10% on the price of admission to public movie theaters when they show films that contain actual or simulated scenes of human sexual intercourse.Which of the following is the strongest argument against the constitutionality of this federal law?
column4: The act imposes a prior restraint on the freedom of speech protected by the First Amendment.
column5: The act is not rationally related to any legitimate national interest.
column6: The act violates the equal protection concepts embodied in the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment because it imposes a tax on the price of admission to view certain films and not on the price of admission to view comparable live performances.
column7: The act imposes a tax solely on the basis of the content of speech without adequate justification and, therefore, it is prohibited by the freedom of speech clause of the First Amendment.

column3: A man fell while attempting to climb a mountain, and lay unconscious and critically injured on a ledge that was difficult to reach. A rescuer, an experienced mountain climber, was himself seriously injured while trying to rescue the man. The rescuer's rescue attempt failed, and the man died of his injuries before he could be reached.The rescuer brought an action against the man's estate for compensation for his injuries. In this jurisdiction, the traditional common-law rules relating to contributory negligence and assumption of risk remain in effect.Will the rescuer prevail in his action against the man's estate?
column4: Yes, if the rescuer’s rescue attempt was reasonable;
column5: Yes, because the law should not discourage attempts to assist persons in helpless peril;
column6: No, unless the man's peril arose from his own failure to exercise reasonable care;
column7: No, because the rescuer’s rescue attempt failed and therefore did not benefit the man.

column3: At a party for coworkers at a man’s home, coworker accused the man of making advances toward his wife. Coworker and his wife left the party. The next day at work, the man saw coworker and struck him on the head with a soft-drink bottle. The coworker fell into a coma and died two weeks after the incident.This jurisdiction defines aggravated assault as an assault with any weapon or dangerous implement and punishes it as a felony. It defines murder as the unlawful killing of a person with malice aforethought or in the course of an independent felony. The man may be found guilty of murder
column4: only if the jury finds that the man intended to kill the coworker.
column5: only if the jury finds that the man did not act in a rage provoked by coworker’s accusations.
column6: if the jury finds that the man intended either to kill or to inflict serious bodily harm.
column7: if the jury finds that the killing occurred in the course of an aggravated assault.

column3: A woman was driving through an intersection when she was hit by a delivery truck driven by a man. The man was texting when he drove through a red light and slammed into the side of the woman's vehicle. The woman sustained serious damages. The woman brought a suit for her injuries and named both the man and the delivery truck owner as parties to the lawsuit. After a brief trial the jury returned a verdict and found the delivery truck owner liable for the damages, but did not find any liability against the man. Counsel for the delivery truck owner asked the court to have the jury reconsider the verdict. The Judge refused counsel's request and ordered the verdict to stand. The Judge's ruling was:
column4: Proper because there was no error on the part of the jury.
column5: Proper because even if there was an error by the jury it was not one that the Judge could correct and would need to reviewed on appeal.
column6: Improper because a Judge must always have a jury reconsider a verdict when a party makes a timely request.
column7: Improper because the verdict was inconsistent and erroneous.

column3: A City ordinance makes the city building inspector responsible for ensuring that all buildings in that city are kept up to building code standards, and requires the inspector to refer for prosecution all known building code violations. Another ordinance provides that the city building inspector may be discharged for "good cause." The building inspector took a newspaper reporter through a number of run-down buildings in a slum neighborhood. After using various epithets and slurs to describe the occupants of these buildings, the building inspector stated to the reporter: "I do not even try to get these buildings up to code or to have their owners prosecuted for code violations because if these buildings are repaired, the people who live in them will just wreck them again." The reporter published these statements in a story in the local newspaper. The building inspector admitted he made the statements.On the basis of these statements, the city council discharged the building inspector. Is the action of the city council constitutional?
column4: Yes, because the statements demonstrate that the building inspector has an attitude toward a certain class of persons that interferes with the proper performance of the obligations of his job.
column5: Yes, because the building inspector is a government employee and a person holding such a position may not make public comments inconsistent with current governmental policy.
column6: No, because the statements were lawful comments on a matter of public concern.
column7: No, because the statements were published in a newspaper that is protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

column3: A man domiciled in Pennsylvania sues a corporation with its principal place of business in New York, in Federal District Court in New York, for state law breach of contract arising from the corporation’s failure to pay royalties on the man’s book. After trial, judgment is for the man in the amount of $500,000. The corporation appeals on various substantive law and evidentiary grounds, but the Second Circuit Court of Appeals affirms the judgment. The U.S. Supreme Court declines to hear the case, and the Second Circuit Court of Appeals issues a remittitur, ending the case. One week after the remittitur is issued, the corporation’s in-house counsel realizes that their litigation counsel failed to move for dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, even though the corporation is incorporated in Pennsylvania, so that there was in reality no diversity of citizenship. The corporation retains new litigation counsel, and files a motion in the Federal District Court, seeking cancellation of the judgment, and dismissal of the Complaint. The District Court should:
column4: Grant the motion on the grounds that it never had subject matter jurisdiction.
column5: Grant the motion if it finds that the man knew he improperly filed the case in District Court.
column6: Deny the motion.
column7: Deny the motion if, and only if, the Court finds that the question of jurisdiction was not litigated previously.

column3: A defendant is on trial in federal court for bank robbery. Before the police had any suspects, a police officer interviewed an eyewitness at the police station and showed her a "mug book" containing dozens of photographs. The eyewitness identified the defendant's photograph as that of the robber.At trial, the eyewitness surprises the prosecutor by testifying that she is unable to identify the defendant as the robber. The prosecutor calls the officer to testify that the eyewitness identified the defendant from the photograph in the police station. The eyewitness remains present in the courthouse and can be recalled.Is the officer's testimony admissible?
column4: No, because the eyewitness was unable to identify the defendant at trial.
column5: No, because the eyewitness's testimony has disappointed the prosecutor but has not affirmatively harmed the prosecution's case.
column6: Yes, because the eyewitness's statement of identification as reported by the officer is not excluded by the hearsay rule.
column7: Yes, because the hearsay rule does not exclude out-of-court statements if a declarant testifies and is available for cross-examination.

column3: A defendant has been charged with selling cocaine to a police informant. At trial, the alleged cocaine no longer exists, and the only evidence that the substance sold was cocaine is the informant's testimony that it tasted like cocaine and gave her a cocaine-like sensation. The informant has no formal training in identifying controlled substances.Should the court admit the informant's opinion testimony that the substance was cocaine?
column4: No, because identification of a controlled substance requires an expert with formal training.
column5: No, because, without a quantity of the controlled substance for testing, opinion testimony is insufficient to make a prima facie case against the defendant.
column6: Yes, if the court determines that the informant has sufficient knowledge and experience to identify cocaine.
column7: Yes, provided there is evidence sufficient to support a jury finding that the informant has sufficient knowledge and experience to identify cocaine.

column3: A man owned in fee simple a farm of 500 acres. He died and by will duly admitted to probate devised the farm to his surviving widow for life with remainder in fee simple to his three children. All three children survived the man.At the time of the man’s death, there existed a mortgage on the farm that the man had given ten years before to secure a loan for the purchase of the farm. At his death, there remained unpaid $40,000 in principal, payable in installments of $4,000 per year for the next ten years. In addition, there was due interest at the rate of 10% per annum, payable annually with the installment of principal. The widow took possession and out of a gross income of $50,000 per year realized $25,000 net after paying all expenses and charges except the installment of principal and interest due on the mortgage.Two of the children wanted all three children to each contribute one-third of the amounts needed to pay the mortgage installments. The third child objected, saying that the widow should pay all of these amounts out of the profits she had made in operation of the farm. When foreclosure of the mortgage seemed imminent, the third child sought legal advice.If the third child obtained sound advice relating to her rights, she was told that
column4: her only protection would lie in instituting an action for partition to compel the sale of the life estate of the widow and to obtain the value of the third child’s one-third interest in remainder.
column5: she could obtain appropriate relief to compel the widow personally to pay the sums due because the income is more than adequate to cover these amounts.
column6: she could be compelled personally to pay her share of the amounts due because discharge of the mortgage enhances the principal.
column7: she could not be held personally liable for any amount but that her share in remainder could be lost if the mortgage installments are not paid.

column3: A radio manufacturer and a retailer, after extensive negotiations, entered into a final, written agreement in which the manufacturer agreed to sell and the retailer agreed to buy all of its requirements of radios, estimated at 20 units per month, during the period January 1, 1988, and December 31, 1990, at a price of $50 per unit. A dispute arose in late December, 1990, when the retailer returned 25 undefective radios to the manufacturer for full credit after the manufacturer had refused to extend the contract for a second three-year period.In an action by the manufacturer against the retailer for damages due to return of the 25 radios, the manufacturer introduces the written agreement, which expressly permitted the buyer to return defective radios for credit but was silent as to return of undefective radios for credit. The retailer seeks to introduce evidence that during the three years of the agreement it had returned, for various reasons, 125 undefective radios, for which the manufacturer had granted full credit. The manufacturer objects to the admissibility of this evidence.The trial court will probably rule that the evidence proffered by the retailer is
column4: inadmissible, because the evidence is barred by the parol evidence rule.
column5: inadmissible, because the express terms of the agreement control when those terms are inconsistent with the course of performance.
column6: admissible, because the evidence supports an agreement that is not within the relevant statute of frauds.
column7: admissible, because course-of-performance evidence, when available, is considered the best indication of what the parties intended the writing to mean.

column3: A woman prepared an accurate statement of her financial condition and submitted it with a loan application to a local bank with which she had done business for many years. Shortly thereafter, the woman's financial condition worsened significantly, but she failed to disclose this fact to the bank. Unaware of the woman's changed financial condition, the bank then agreed to lend money to the woman.The bank later learned of the woman's true financial condition. The bank refused to honor its promise to lend money to the woman, contending that the parties' contract was voidable at the bank's option because of the woman's misrepresentation.If the woman sues the bank for breach of contract, will the bank's misrepresentation defense likely succeed?
column4: No, because the woman did not make any subsequent affirmative misrepresentations about her financial condition.
column5: No, because the woman's representations were accurate at the time she submitted the loan application to the bank.
column6: Yes, because the woman had an obligation to correct her previous representations about her financial condition in order to prevent them from being fraudulent.
column7: Yes, because the woman had an obligation to tell the bank about her changed financial condition due to the longstanding relationship of trust and confidence between them.

column3: A company incorporated and headquartered in State A sued a plumber domiciled in State B in a federal court in State A, alleging that the plumber had negligently installed pipes in a manner that resulted in $250,000 in damage to the company's headquarters building. In response to the complaint, the plumber filed a motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction. The court denied the motion. Thereafter, the plumber did not file an answer or any other response to the company's action.Sixty days after the court's order denying the motion to dismiss, the company asked the clerk to enter default, and the clerk did so. The company applied to the court for the entry of a default judgment and notified the plumber three days before the default judgment hearing. After an ex parte hearing in which the court received evidence on the damages amount, the court entered a default judgment for the full amount sought. Ten days later, the plumber filed a motion to set aside the default judgment.Is the court likely to grant the plumber's motion?
column4: No, because the court could fix the amount of damages even without hearing the plumber's evidence.
column5: No, because the plumber failed to plead or otherwise defend against the company's action.
column6: Yes, because the plumber was not given adequate notice of the hearing on the company's application for the entry of a default judgment.
column7: Yes, because the State A federal court lacked personal jurisdiction over the plumber as a State B citizen.

column3: A woman resident of San Francisco, California, brought a personal injury claim in Federal District Court in California, Northern District, against: (1) first corporation, a corporation incorporated in Delaware with its principal place of business in New York; and (2) second corporation, a corporation incorporated in Arizona with its principal place of business in Nevada. First corporation manufactured the machine which badly mangled the woman’s hand and arm when it malfunctioned while she was using it at her place of work in San Francisco, and second corporation negligently inspected the machine shortly before the accident which injured the woman. Second corporation maintains its offices, from which it sends maintenance crews throughout California, in San Diego, in the Southern District of California.If second corporation moves for a change of venue from the Northern District to the Southern District, which is the most likely basis on which the court would find that venue in the Southern District is proper?
column4: The Southern District is one in which second corporation resides.
column5: There is personal jurisdiction over second corporation throughout the state.
column6: Second corporation maintains its offices in the Southern District, and thus is subject to personal jurisdiction in the Southern District.
column7: First corporation is subject to jurisdiction anywhere in California and thus cannot object to changes in venue.

column3: Defendant was prosecuted for sexually abusing his 13-year-old stepdaughter. The stepdaughter testified to Defendant's conduct. On cross-examination, defense counsel asks the stepdaughter, "Isn't it true that shortly before you complained that Defendant abused you, he punished you for maliciously ruining some of his CD’s?"The question is:
column4: proper, because it relates to a possible motive for the stepdaughter to accuse Defendant falsely.
column5: proper, because the stepdaughter 's misconduct is relevant to her character for veracity.
column6: improper, because the incident had nothing to do with the stepdaughter's truthfulness.
column7: improper, because it falls outside the scope of direct examination.

column3: A man entered the county museum at a time when it was open to the public, intending to steal a Picasso etching. Once inside, he took what he thought was the etching from an unlocked display case and concealed it under his coat. However, the etching was a photocopy of an original that had been loaned to another museum. A sign over the display case containing the photocopy said that similar photocopies were available free at the entrance. The man did not see the sign.Burglary in the jurisdiction is defined as “entering a building unlawfully with the intent to commit a crime.”The man is guilty of
column4: burglary and larceny.
column5: burglary and attempted larceny.
column6: larceny.
column7: attempted larceny.

column3: Insurance is provided in a State only by private companies. Although the state insurance commissioner inspects insurance companies for solvency, the state does not regulate their rates or policies. An insurance company charges higher rates for burglary insurance to residents of one part of a county in the State than to residents of another section of the same county because of the different crime rates in those areas.A woman is a resident of that county who was charged the higher rate by the insurance company because of the location of her residence. The woman sues the insurance company, alleging that the differential in insurance rates unconstitutionally denies her the equal protection of the laws. Will the woman's suit succeed?
column4: Yes, because the higher crime rate in the woman's neighborhood demonstrates that the county police are not giving persons who reside there the equal protection of the laws.
column5: Yes, because the insurance rate differential is inherently discriminatory.
column6: No, because the constitutional guarantee of equal protection of the laws is not applicable to the actions of these insurance companies.
column7: No, because there is a rational basis for the differential in insurance rates.

column3: A bank teller, was fired by the president of the bank. The teller decided to take revenge against the bank president, but decided against attempting it personally, because he knew that the bank president was protected around the clock by bank security guards. The teller knew that his friend had a violent temper and was very jealous. The teller falsely told the friend that the friend’s wife was having an affair with the bank president. Enraged, the friend said, “What am I going to do?” The teller said, “If it were my wife, I’d just march into his office and blow his brains out.” The friend grabbed a revolver and rushed to the bank. He walked into the bank, carrying the gun in his hand. One of the security guards, believing that a holdup was about to occur, shot and killed the friend.If charged with the murder of the friend, the teller should be found:
column4: guilty, based upon extreme recklessness.
column5: guilty, based upon transferred intent.
column6: not guilty, because he did not intend for the friend to be shot by the security guard.
column7: not guilty, because he did not shoot the friend and he was not acting in concert with the security guard.

column3: Without a warrant, police officers searched the garbage cans in the alley behind a man's house and discovered chemicals used to make methamphetamine, as well as cooking utensils and containers with the man's fingerprints on them. The alley was a public thoroughfare maintained by the city, and the garbage was picked up once a week by a private sanitation company. The items were found inside the garbage cans in plastic bags that had been tied closed and further secured with tape. The man was charged in federal court with the manufacture of methamphetamine.Did the search of the garbage cans violate the Fourth Amendment?
column4: No, because the man had no reasonable expectation of privacy in garbage left in the alley.
column5: No, because the probative value of the evidence outweighs the man's modest privacy claims in his garbage.
column6: Yes, because the alley was within the curtilage of the man's home and entry without a warrant was unconstitutional.
column7: Yes, because there is a reasonable expectation of privacy in one's secured garbage containers.

column3: A new, comprehensive federal statute was recently enacted to deal with the public health crisis caused by opioid addiction. Congress and the President were concerned that inconsistent lower court rulings with respect to the constitutionality, interpretation, and application of the statute might adversely affect or delay its enforcement and, thereby, jeopardize the public health. As a result, they included a provision in the statute providing that all legal challenges concerning those matters may be initiated only by filing suit directly in the United States Supreme Court.The provision authorizing direct review of the constitutionality, interpretation, or application of this statute only in the United States Supreme Court is:
column4: constitutional, because it is authorized by the Article I power of Congress to enact all laws that are "necessary and proper" to implement the general welfare.
column5: constitutional, because Article III provides that the jurisdiction of the United States Supreme Court is subject to such exceptions and such regulations as Congress shall make.
column6: unconstitutional, because it denies persons who wish to challenge this statute the equal protection of the laws by requiring them to file suit in a court different from that in which persons who wish to challenge other statutes may file suit.
column7: unconstitutional, because it is inconsistent with the specification in Article III of the original jurisdiction of the United States Supreme Court.

column3: A defendant was convicted of fraud after a jury trial in state court. The conviction was affirmed on direct appeal.The defendant timely moved for postconviction relief under the Sixth Amendment on the ground that his attorney had provided ineffective assistance of counsel. The trial judge, after a hearing, found that the attorney had performed deficiently by failing to raise a proper objection that would have resulted in exclusion of important prosecution evidence.What more, if anything, must the trial court find in order to sustain the defendant's Sixth Amendment claim?
column4: Nothing more, because the unjustifiable failure to object to important prosecution evidence is structural error.
column5: That the attorney was court-appointed and not privately retained.
column6: That there is a reasonable probability that the trial's outcome would have been different if the attorney had objected.
column7: That there is clear and convincing evidence that the trial's outcome would have been different if the attorney had objected.

column3: A young woman told a young man she would like to have sexual intercourse with him and that he should come to her apartment that night at 7 p.m. After the young man arrived, he and the young woman went into the bedroom. As the young man started to remove the young woman’s blouse, the young woman said she had changed her mind. The young man tried to convince her to have intercourse with him, but after ten minutes of her sustained refusals, the young man left the apartment. Unknown to the young man, the young woman was 15 years old. Because she appeared to be older, the young man believed her to be about 18 years old.A statute in this jurisdiction provides: “A person commits rape in the second degree if he has sexual intercourse with a girl, not his wife, who is under the age of 16 years.”If the young man is charged with attempting to violate this statute, he is
column4: guilty, because no mental state is required as to the element of age.
column5: guilty, because he persisted after she told him she had changed her mind.
column6: not guilty, because he reasonably believed she had consented and voluntarily withdrew after she told him she had changed her mind.
column7: not guilty, because he did not intend to have intercourse with a girl under the age of 16.

column3: For this question only, assume the following facts. If the man had started to paint on the following Saturday morning, he could have finished before Sunday evening. However, he stayed home that Saturday morning to watch the final game of the World Series on TV, and did not start to paint until Saturday afternoon. By late Saturday afternoon, the man realized that he had underestimated the time it would take to finish the job if he continued to work alone. The man phoned the woman at her home and accurately informed her that it was impossible to finish the work over the weekend unless he hired a helper. He also stated that to do so would require an additional charge of $200 for the work. The woman told the man that she apparently had no choice but to pay “whatever it takes” to get the work done as scheduled.The man hired another painter to help finish the painting and paid the other painter $200. The woman has offered to pay the man $1,000. The man is demanding $1,200.How much is the man likely to recover?
column4: $1,000 only, because the woman received no consideration for her promise to pay the additional sum.
column5: $1,000 only, because the woman’s promise to pay “whatever it takes” is too uncertain to be enforceable.
column6: $1,200, in order to prevent the woman’s unjust enrichment.
column7: $1,200, because the impossibility of the man’s completing the work alone discharged the original contract and a new contract was formed.

column3: For this question only, assume the following facts. The man commenced work on Saturday morning, and had finished half the painting by the time he quit work for the day. That night, without the fault of either party, the office building was destroyed by fire.Which of the following is an accurate statement?
column4: Both parties’ contractual duties are discharged, and the man can recover nothing from the woman.
column5: Both parties’ contractual duties are discharged, but the man can recover in quasi-contract from the woman.
column6: Only the man’s contractual duty is discharged, because the woman’s performance (payment of the agreed price) is not impossible.
column7: Only the man’s contractual duty is discharged, and the man can recover his reliance damages from the woman.

column3: A state law required vacant public school buildings to be sold at auction to the highest bidder. A church in a city located in the state wanted to acquire larger facilities for its school. The city's school board proposed a new state law that would authorize it to sell a vacant public school building, at a price below its fair market value, to the church for use as its school.If enacted, would this law be constitutional?
column4: No, because a statute specially authorizing the sale of the building without competitive bidding would violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
column5: No, because the transfer of the building to the church under these circumstances would constitute an establishment of religion prohibited by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.
column6: Yes, because surplus government property is not subject to the limitations imposed by the establishment clause as incorporated into the Fourteenth Amendment.
column7: Yes, because the law would not primarily or substantially support the religious activities of the church.

column3: A landlord leased an apartment to a tenant on a month-to-month basis beginning on the first of the month, with rent payable monthly. Five months into the lease, the tenant failed to pay rent. The landlord then sued the tenant for possession for nonpayment of rent. The tenant successfully defended this suit on the ground that the apartment was uninhabitable and that, accordingly, no rent was properly payable.On May 7, immediately following the court order in the tenant's favor, the landlord served the tenant with a written but not notarized notice to terminate the tenancy and to vacate the apartment on or before June 30.On July 1, the tenant was still in possession, nothing had changed, and the landlord brought an appropriate action for possession. The tenant prevailed.What is the most likely reason for the court's decision?
column4: A six-month notice was required to terminate this periodic tenancy.
column5: The landlord did not give the tenant a notarized notice of termination.
column6: The landlord was attempting to terminate the tenancy as a reaction to the tenant's defense in the previous lawsuit.
column7: The landlord's notice to terminate was improper, because it was given to the tenant more than one month before the required termination date.

column3: In order to provide funds for a system of new major airports near the ten largest cities in the United States, Congress levies a tax of $25 on each airline ticket issued in the United States. The tax applies to every airline ticket, even those for travel that does not originate in, terminate at, or pass through any of those ten large cities. As applied to the issuance in the United States of an airline ticket for travel between two cities that will not be served by any of the new airports, this tax is:
column4: constitutional, because Congress has broad discretion in choosing the subjects of its taxation and may impose taxes on subjects that have no relation to the purpose for which those tax funds will be expended.
column5: constitutional, because an exemption for the issuance of tickets for travel between cities that will not be served by the new airports would deny the purchasers of all other tickets the equal protection of the laws.
column6: unconstitutional, because the burden of the tax outweighs its benefits for passengers whose travel does not originate in, terminate at, or pass through any of the ten largest cities.
column7: unconstitutional, because the tax adversely affects the fundamental right to travel.

column2: Real Property,  Easements,  Covenants and Servitudes
column3: A man conveyed the eastern half of a tract of vacant land to a woman by a warranty deed. The woman promptly recorded the deed. The land conveyed to the woman fronted on a public highway. The land retained by the man was landlocked.One year later, the man died intestate, leaving a cousin as his only heir. The cousin visited the man's land for the first time and discovered that it had no access to a public highway. A neighbor who owned adjoining land fronting on the public highway offered to sell the cousin a right to cross the neighbor's land for access to the highway. Although the neighbor's price was reasonable, the cousin rejected the offer. The woman has refused to allow the cousin to cross her land for access to the public highway even though the woman's land is still vacant.The cousin has sued the woman, seeking access across the woman's land to the public highway. Who is likely to prevail?
column4: The cousin, based on necessity.
column5: The cousin, because the woman's land is still vacant.
column6: The woman, because the cousin could obtain an alternative access to the highway from the neighbor.
column7: The woman, because the man failed to reserve an easement in his deed to the woman.

column3: Plaintiff sued Defendant for personal injuries sustained when Defendant's car hit Plaintiff, a pedestrian. Immediately after the accident, Defendant got out of his car, raced over to Plaintiff, and said, "Don't worry, I'll pay your hospital bill."Plaintiff 's testimony concerning Defendant's statement is:
column4: admissible, because it is an admission of liability by a party opponent.
column5: admissible, because it is within the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule.
column6: inadmissible to prove liability, because it is an offer to pay medical expenses.
column7: inadmissible, provided that Defendant kept his promise to pay Plaintiff 's medical expenses.

column3: One evening, a man had several drinks and then started to drive home. As he was proceeding down Main Boulevard, an automobile pulled out of a side street to his right. The man’s car struck this automobile broadside. The driver of the other car was killed as a result of the collision. A breath analysis test administered after the accident showed that the man satisfied the legal definition of intoxication.If the man is prosecuted for manslaughter, his best chance for acquittal would be based on an argument that
column4: the other driver was contributorily negligent.
column5: he collision would have occurred even if the man had not been intoxicated.
column6: because of his intoxication he lacked the mens rea needed for manslaughter.
column7: driving while intoxicated requires no mens rea and so cannot be the basis for misdemeanor manslaughter.

column3: A seller and a buyer, standing on a tract of real property, orally agreed to its sale and purchase for $5,000, and orally marked its bounds as “that line of trees down there, the ditch that intersects them, the fence on the other side, and that street on the fourth side.”In which of the following is the remedy of reformation most appropriate?
column4: As later reduced to writing, the agreement by clerical mistake included two acres that are actually beyond the fence.
column5: Buyer reasonably thought that two acres beyond the fence were included in the oral agreement but seller did not. As later reduced to writing, the agreement included the two acres.
column6: Buyer reasonably thought that the price orally agreed upon was $4,500, but seller did not. As later reduced to writing, the agreement said $5,000.
column7: Buyer reasonably thought that a dilapidated shed backed up against the fence was to be torn down and removed as part of the agreement, but seller did not. As later reduced to writing, the agreement said nothing about the shed.

column3: A company operates an aircraft maintenance and repair business serving the needs of owners of private airplanes. A man contracted with the company to replace the engine in his plane with a more powerful engine of foreign manufacture. The company purchased the replacement engine through a representative of the manufacturer and installed it in the man's plane. A short time after it was put into use, the new engine failed, and the plane crashed into a warehouse, destroying the warehouse and its contents. The company was guilty of no negligence in the procurement, inspection, or installation of the engine. The failure of the engine was caused by a defect that would not be disclosed by inspection and testing procedures available to an installer. There was no negligence on the part of the man, who escaped the disabled plane by parachute.The warehouse owner recovered a judgment for damages from the man for the destruction of his warehouse and its contents, and the man has asserted a claim against the company to recover compensation on account of that liability. In that action, the man will recover:
column4: full compensation, because the engine was defective;
column5: no compensation, because the company was not negligent;
column6: contribution only, because the company and the man were equally innocent;
column7: no compensation, because the warehouse owner’s judgment established the man's responsibility to the warehouse owner.

column3: To encourage the growth of its population, a State established a program that awarded $1,000 to the parents of each child born within the state, provided that at the time of the child's birth the mother and father of the newborn were citizens of the United States. Plaintiffs are aliens who are permanent residents of the United States and have resided in the State for three years. When their first child was born two months ago, they applied for and were denied the $1,000 award by State officials on the sole ground that they are not citizens of the United States. The Plaintiffs filed suit in federal court contending that their exclusion from the award program was unconstitutional. Assume no federal statute addresses this question.In this case, the court should hold that the exclusion of legal permanent resident aliens from the State award program is:
column4: constitutional, because the Tenth Amendment reserves to the states plenary authority over the spending of state funds.
column5: constitutional, because the State has a legitimate interest in encouraging the growth of its population, and a rational legislature could believe that families in which both parents are United States citizens are more likely to stay in the State and contribute to its future prosperity than those in which one or both of the parents are aliens.
column6: unconstitutional, because strict scrutiny governs judicial review of such state classifications based on alienage, and the State cannot demonstrate that this classification is necessary to advance a compelling state interest.
column7: unconstitutional, because state classifications based on alienage are impermissible unless explicitly authorized by an act of Congress.

column3: A pilot was flying his small plane when he experienced engine trouble and was forced to make an emergency landing. He landed the plane safely in a large yard behind a home located in a relatively remote area. Unfortunately, when he disembarked from the plane, he was attacked and injured by two large dogs kept by the homeowner to discourage trespassers. The homeowner, who had seen the plane land, had ordered the dogs to attack. Several months earlier, the homeowner had posted large signs around the perimeter of the yard warning of the dogs.Does the pilot have a viable claim against the homeowner for battery?
column4: No, because the homeowner had provided adequate warning.
column5: No, because the pilot was a trespasser.
column6: Yes, because the pilot can invoke the privilege of necessity.
column7: Yes, because the pilot could not reasonably have been expected to see the warning signs posted by the homeowner.

column3: A woman and a man are both passengers on a bus owned and operated by a California corporation. The bus is negligently driven and collides with a truck on the freeway, and a number of passengers, including the woman and the man, are injured. The woman, a resident of New Mexico, files suit in Federal Court in California, claiming damages of $80,000. If the man files a motion seeking permission to join in the woman’s action, claiming damages of $20,000:
column4: The motion will be denied, because the man cannot meet the amount in controversy requirement.
column5: The motion will be denied, since the man cannot aggregate his claims with Pam’s.
column6: The motion will be granted, since both claims arise out of the same occurrence and there is a question of law common to both parties.
column7: The motion will be granted, solely on the basis of supplemental jurisdiction.

column3: City police officers shot and killed a man's friend as he attempted to escape arrest for an armed robbery he had committed. The man brought suit in federal district court against the City Police Department and the city police officers involved, seeking only a judgment declaring unconstitutional the state statute under which the police acted. That newly enacted statute authorized the police to use deadly force when necessary to apprehend a person who has committed a felony. In his suit, the man alleged that the police would not have killed his friend if the use of deadly force had not been authorized by the statute.The federal district court should:
column4: decide the case on its merits, because it raises a substantial federal question.
column5: dismiss the action, because it involves a nonjusticiable political question.
column6: dismiss the action, because it does not present a case or controversy.
column7: dismiss the action, because the Eleventh Amendment prohibits federal courts from deciding cases of this type.

column3: The attorney for defendant in a case alleging that a product manufactured by defendant is toxic and harmful to humans retains a microbiologist as an expert in anticipation of trial to advise the attorney regarding the toxicity of the product and the risk, if any, it poses to humans. The microbiologist examines the product, conducts tests on it and prepares a report for the attorney. Which of the following statements is correct?
column4: If the attorney does not expect to call the microbiologist as a witness at trial, the attorney must provide plaintiff’s attorney with a copy of the microbiologist’s report, but the microbiologist will not have to appear for deposition.
column5: If the attorney does not expect to call the microbiologist as a witness at trial, the attorney must provide plaintiff’s attorney with a copy of the microbiologist’s report and Edward will have to appear for deposition if requested by plaintiff’s attorney.
column6: If the attorney expects to call the microbiologist as a witness at trial, the attorney must provide plaintiff’s attorney with a copy of the microbiologist’s report and any drafts of the report reviewed by the attorney.
column7: If the attorney expects to call the microbiologist as a witness at trial, the attorney must provide plaintiff’s attorney with a copy of the microbiologist’s report and the microbiologist will have to appear for deposition if requested by plaintiff’s attorney.

column3: A plaintiff filed a tort action in state court but then failed to prosecute the action. The defendant moved to dismiss the action, and the court granted the motion in an order that stated: "The defendant's motion to dismiss is granted, and this action is dismissed with prejudice." The court accordingly entered judgment for the defendant.The plaintiff then filed the same claim against the defendant in federal court, invoking diversity jurisdiction. The defendant has asserted the defense of res judicata (claim preclusion) in its answer.Should the federal court give preclusive effect to the state court judgment?
column4: No, because the judgment was entered by a state court, not a federal court.
column5: No, because the state court did not rule on the merits in its dismissal.
column6: Yes, because a dismissal with prejudice operates as a judgment on the merits.
column7: Yes, because a judgment for failure to prosecute operates as a judgment on the merits under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

column3: A man contracted with an interstate carrier, to ship household goods across country to his new home in a State. A federal statute provides that all liability of an interstate mover to a shipper for loss of or damage to the shipper's goods in transit is governed exclusively by the contract between them. The statute also requires the mover to offer a shipper at least two contracts with different levels of liability. In full compliance with that federal statute, the carrier offered the man a choice between two shipping agreements that provided different levels of liability on the part of the carrier. The more expensive contract provided that the carrier was fully liable in case of loss or damage. The less expensive contract limited the carrier's liability in case of loss or damage to less than full value. The man voluntarily signed the less expensive contract with the carrier, fixing the carrier's liability at less than the full value of the shipment.The carrier's truck was involved in an accident in the State. The accident was entirely a product of the negligence of the carrier's driver. The man's household goods were totally destroyed. In accordance with the contract, the carrier reimbursed the man for less than the full value of the goods. The man then brought suit against the carrier under the tort law of the State claiming that he was entitled to be reimbursed for the full value of the goods. The carrier filed a motion to dismiss.In this suit, the court should:
column4: dismiss the case, because the federal statute governing liability of interstate carriers is the supreme law of the land and preempts state tort law.
column5: dismiss the case, because the contractual relationship between the man and the carrier is governed by the obligation of contracts clause of the Constitution.
column6: deny the motion to dismiss, because the full faith and credit clause of the Constitution requires that state tort law be given effect.
column7: deny the motion to dismiss, because it is unconstitutional for a federal statute to authorize the carrier to contract out of any degree of liability for its own negligence.

column3: The owner of a meatpacking company was charged under a state criminal code prohibiting the sale of contaminated meat. The state's highest court has construed the code as imposing strict and vicarious liability to the extent allowed by the federal Constitution.The evidence at trial established that the owner's company had sold contaminated meat that had sickened hundreds of consumers. It further showed, however, that the owner had been out of the country when the meat was sold and had had no reason to know that any of the meat was contaminated.The jury convicted the owner, and the court sentenced him to a large fine and probation. On appeal, the owner has challenged the sufficiency of the trial evidence.Should the appellate court uphold the conviction?
column4: No, because there was insufficient proof of the owner's actus reus.
column5: No, because there was insufficient proof of the owner's mens rea.
column6: Yes, because an appellate court cannot second-guess a jury's verdict.
column7: Yes, because the evidence was sufficient to support the jury’s verdict.

column3: City operates a cemetery pursuant to a city ordinance. The ordinance requires the operation of the city cemetery to be supported primarily by revenues derived from the sale of cemetery lots to individuals. The ordinance further provides that the purchase of a cemetery lot entitles the owner to perpetual care of the lot, and entitles the owner to erect on the lot, at the owner's expense, a memorial monument or marker of the owner's choice, subject to certain size restrictions. The City ordinance requires the city to maintain the cemetery, including mowing the grass, watering flowers, and plowing snow, and provides for the expenditure of city tax funds for such maintenance if revenues from the sale of cemetery lots are insufficient. Although cemetery lots are sold at full fair market value, which includes the current value of perpetual care, the revenue from the sale of such lots has been insufficient in recent years to maintain the cemetery. As a result, a small amount of city tax funds has also been used for that purpose.A group of City taxpayers brings suit against City challenging the constitutionality of the city ordinance insofar as it permits the owner of a cemetery lot to erect a religious memorial monument or marker on his or her lot.Is this suit likely to be successful?
column4: No, because only a small amount of city tax funds has been used to maintain the cemetery.
